adj. 1 each single (heard every word). 2 each at a specified interval in a series (comes every four days). 3 all possible (every prospect of success).
pron. Every person.
attrib. Adj. 1 occurring every day. 2 used on ordinary days. 3 commonplace.
n. Ordinary or typical human being. [name of a character in a 15th-c. Morality play]
pron. Everybody.
n. Each one.
pron. 1 all things. 2 most important thing (speed is everything).
adv. 1 in every place. 2 colloq. In many places.
v. Expel (a tenant etc.) By legal process.

n. 1 (often foll. By for, of) available facts, circumstances, etc. Indicating whether or not a thing is true or valid. 2 law a information tending to prove a fact or proposition. B statements or proofs admissible as testimony in a lawcourt. v. (-cing) be evidence of.
adj. Plain or obvious; manifest. [latin: related to *evidence]
adj. Of or providing evidence.
adv. 1 seemingly; as it appears. 2 as shown by evidence.
adj. 1 morally bad; wicked. 2 harmful. 3 disagreeable (evil temper). n. 1 evil thing. 2 wickedness.
n. Sinner.
n. Gaze that is superstitiously believed to cause harm.
v. (-cing) indicate, display (a quality, feeling, etc.). [latin: related to *evict]
v. (-ting) disembowel.
adj. Evoking (esp. Feelings or memories).
v. (-king) inspire or draw forth (memories, a response, etc.).

n. 1 gradual development. 2 development of species from earlier forms, as an explanation of their origins. 3 unfolding of events etc. (evolution of the plot). 4 change in the disposition of troops or ships.
n. Person who regards evolution as explaining the origin of species.
v. (-ving) 1 develop gradually and naturally. 2 devise (a theory, plan, etc.). 3 unfold. 4 give off (gas, heat, etc.). [latin volvo volut- roll]
n. Female sheep. [old english]
n. Water-jug with a wide mouth. [latin aqua water]
prep. (of goods) sold from (ex-works). [latin, = out of]
n. Colloq. Former husband or wife. [see *ex-1 2]

prefix (also before some consonants e-, ef- before f) 1 forming verbs meaning: a out, forth (exclude; exit). B upward (extol). C thoroughly (excruciate). D bring into a state (exasperate). E remove or free from (expatriate; exonerate). 2 forming nouns from titles of office, status, etc., meaning formerly (ex-president; ex-wife). [latin from ex out of]
prefix out (exodus). [greek]
v. (-ting) 1 make (pain etc.) Worse. 2 irritate (a person).
adj. 1 accurate; correct in all details (exact description). 2 precise. v. 1 demand and enforce payment of (money etc.). 2 demand; insist on; require.
adj. 1 making great demands. 2 requiring much effort.
n. 1 exacting or being exacted. 2 a illegal or exorbitant demand; extortion. B sum or thing exacted.
n. Exactness, precision.
adv. 1 precisely. 2 (said in reply) i quite agree.
n. A science in which absolute precision is possible.
v. (-ting) 1 (also absol.) Make (a thing) seem larger or greater etc. Than it really is. 2 increase beyond normal or due proportions (exaggerated politeness).
v. 1 raise in rank or power etc. 2 praise highly. 3 (usu. As exalted adj.) Make lofty or noble (exalted aims; exalted style).
n. = *examination 3.
n. 1 examining or being examined. 2 detailed inspection. 3 test of proficiency or knowledge by questions. 4 formal questioning of a witness etc. In court.
v. (-ning) 1 inquire into the nature or condition etc. Of. 2 look closely at. 3 test the proficiency of. 4 check the health of (a patient). 5 formally question in court.

n. 1 thing characteristic of its kind or illustrating a general rule. 2 person, thing, or piece of conduct, in terms of its fitness to be imitated. 3 circumstance or treatment seen as a warning to others. 4 problem or exercise designed to illustrate a rule.
v. (-ting) irritate intensely.
adj. & adv. With full authority (esp. Of a papal pronouncement). [latin, = from the chair]
v. (-ting) 1 a make (a hole or channel) by digging. B dig out material from (the ground). 2 reveal or extract by digging. 3 (also absol.) Archaeol. Dig systematically to explore (a site).

v. 1 (often foll. By by an amount) be more or greater than. 2 go beyond or do more than is warranted by (a set limit, esp. Of one's authority, instructions, or rights). 3 surpass. [latin excedo -cess- go beyond]
adv. Extremely.
v. (-ll-) 1 surpass. 2 be pre-eminent. [latin excello be eminent]
n. Outstanding merit or quality. [latin: related to *excel]
n. (pl. -ies) (usu. Prec. By your, his, her, their) title used in addressing or referring to certain high officials.
adj. Extremely good.
var. Of *eccentric (in technical senses).

v. Exclude from a general statement, condition, etc. prep. (often foll. By for) not including; other than (all failed except him; is all right except that it is too long). conj. Archaic unless (except he be born again). [latin excipio -cept- take out]
prep. = *except prep.
excepting should be used only after not and always; otherwise, except should be used.
n. 1 excepting or being excepted. 2 thing that has been or will be excepted. 3 instance that does not follow a rule.
adj. Open to objection.
exceptionable is sometimes confused with exceptional.
adj. 1 forming an exception; unusual. 2 outstanding.
see note at exceptionable.
n. Short extract from a book, film, etc. v. (also absol.) Take excerpts from.

n. 1 exceeding. 2 amount by which one thing exceeds another. 3 a overstepping of accepted limits of moderation, esp. In eating or drinking. B (in pl.) Immoderate behaviour. 4 part of an insurance claim to be paid by the insured. attrib. Adj. Usu. 1 that exceeds a limited or prescribed amount. 2 required as extra payment (excess postage).
n. (also excess luggage) baggage exceeding a weight allowance and liable to an extra charge.
adj. Too much or too great.

n. 1 giving of one thing and receiving of another in its place. 2 giving of money for its equivalent in the money of the same or another country. 3 centre where telephone connections are made. 4 place where merchants, bankers, etc. Transact business. 5 a office where information is given or a service provided. B employment office. 6 system of settling debts without the use of money, by bills of exchange. 7 short conversation. v. (-ging) 1 (often foll. By for) give or receive (one thing) in place of another. 2 give and receive as equivalents. 3 (often foll. By with) make an exchange.
n. Value of one currency in terms of another.
n. 1 former government department in charge of national revenue. 2 royal or national treasury. 3 money of a private individual or group. [medieval latin scaccarium chessboard]
with reference to sense 1, the functions of this department in the uk now belong to the treasury, although the name formally survives, esp. In the title chancellor of the exchequer.

n. 1 tax on goods produced or sold within the country of origin. 2 tax on certain licences. v. (-sing) 1 charge excise on. 2 force (a person) to pay excise. [dutch excijs from romanic: related to latin *census tax]
v. (-sing) 1 remove (a passage from a book etc.). 2 cut out (an organ etc.) By surgery.
adj. Easily excited.
v. (-ting) 1 a rouse the emotions of (a person). B arouse (feelings etc.). C arouse sexually. 2 provoke (an action etc.). 3 stimulate (an organism, tissue, etc.) To activity. [latin cieo stir up]
n. 1 excited state of mind. 2 exciting thing.
adj. Arousing great interest or enthusiasm.
v. 1 cry out suddenly. 2 (foll. By that) utter by exclaiming. [latin: related to *claim]
n. 1 exclaiming. 2 word(s) exclaimed. [latin: related to *exclaim]
n. Punctuation mark (!) Indicating exclamation.
adj. Of or serving as an exclamation.
v. (-ding) 1 keep out (a person or thing) from a place, group, privilege, etc. 2 remove from consideration (no theory can be excluded). 3 make impossible, preclude (excluded all doubt).

adj. 1 excluding other things. 2 (predic.; foll. By of) not including; except for. 3 tending to exclude others, esp. Socially. 4 high-class. 5 not obtainable elsewhere or not published elsewhere. n. Article etc. Published by only one newspaper etc.
v. (-ting) officially exclude (a person) from membership and esp. Sacraments of the church. adj. Excommunicated. n. Excommunicated person.
v. (-ting) 1 a remove skin from (a person etc.) By abrasion. B strip off (skin). 2 censure severely.
n. Faeces.
n. 1 abnormal or morbid outgrowth on the body or a plant. 2 ugly addition.
n.pl. Faeces and urine. [latin: related to *excrete]
v. (-ting) (of an animal or plant) expel (waste matter).
adj. Causing acute mental or physical pain.
v. (-ting) formal (often foll. By from) free from blame; clear of a charge.
n. Journey (usu. A day-trip) to a place and back, made for pleasure. [latin excurro run out]
adj. Literary digressive.

v. (-sing) 1 try to lessen the blame attaching to (a person, act, or fault). 2 (of a fact) serve as a reason to judge (a person or act) less severely. 3 (often foll. By from) release (a person) from a duty etc. 4 forgive (a fault or offence). 5 (foll. By for) forgive (a person) for (a fault). 6 refl. Leave with apologies. n. 1 reason put forward to mitigate or justify an offence. 2 apology (made my excuses).
adj. Not listed in a telephone directory, at one's own request.
adj. Abominable. [latin: related to *execrate]
v. (-ting) 1 express or feel abhorrence for. 2 (also absol.) Curse (a person or thing).

v. (-ting) 1 carry out, perform (a plan, duty etc.). 2 carry out a design for (a product of art or skill). 3 carry out a death sentence on. 4 make (a legal instrument) valid by signing, sealing, etc. [latin sequor follow]
n. 1 carrying out; performance. 2 technique or style of performance in the arts, esp. Music. 3 carrying out of a death sentence. [latin: related to *execute]
n. Official who carries out a death sentence.

n. 1 person or body with managerial or administrative responsibility. 2 branch of a government etc. Concerned with executing laws, agreements, etc. adj. Concerned with executing laws, agreements, etc., or with other administration or management. [medieval latin: related to *execute]
n. (fem. Executrix) person appointed by a testator to administer his or her will.
n. (pl. Exegeses) critical explanation of a text, esp. Of scripture.
n. 1 model. 2 typical or parallel instance. [latin: related to *example]
adj. 1 fit to be imitated; outstandingly good. 2 serving as a warning. 3 illustrative. [latin: related to *example]
v. (-ies, -ied) 1 illustrate by example. 2 be an example of.
adj. (often foll. By from) free from an obligation or liability etc. Imposed on others. v. (foll. By from) make exempt.

n. 1 activity requiring physical effort, done to sustain or improve health. 2 mental or spiritual activity, esp. As practice to develop a faculty. 3 task devised as exercise. 4 a use or application of a mental faculty, right, etc. B practice of an ability, quality, etc. 5 (often in pl.) Military drill or manoeuvres. v. (-sing) 1 use or apply (a faculty, right, etc.). 2 perform (a function). 3 a take (esp. Physical) exercise. B provide (an animal) with exercise. 4 a tax the powers of. B perplex, worry. [latin exerceo keep busy]
v. 1 bring to bear, use (a quality, force, influence, etc.). 2 refl. (often foll. By for, or to + infin.) Use one's efforts or endeavours; strive.
v. 1 bring to bear, use (a quality, force, influence, etc.). 2 refl. (often foll. By for, or to + infin.) Use one's efforts or endeavours; strive.
v. (as a stage direction) (actors) leave the stage. [latin: related to *exit]
v. (-ting) 1 come off in scales or layers. 2 throw off layers of bark.
adv. As a favour; not from (esp. Legal) obligation. attrib. Adj. Granted on this basis. [latin, = from favour]
v. (-ling) 1 breathe out. 2 give off or be given off in vapour.

v. 1 consume or use up the whole of. 2 (often as exhausted adj. Or exhausting adj.) Tire out. 3 study or expound (a subject) completely. 4 (often foll. By of) empty (a vessel etc.) Of its contents. n. 1 waste gases etc. Expelled from an engine after combustion. 2 (also exhaust-pipe) pipe or system by which these are expelled. 3 process of expulsion of these gases.
n. 1 exhausting or being exhausted. 2 total loss of strength.
adj. Thorough, comprehensive.
v. (-t-) 1 show or reveal, esp. Publicly. 2 display (a quality etc.). n. Item displayed, esp. In an exhibition or as evidence in a lawcourt.
n. 1 display (esp. Public) of works of art etc. 2 exhibiting or being exhibited. 3 scholarship, esp. From the funds of a school, college, etc.
n. Student who has been awarded an exhibition.
n. 1 tendency towards attention-seeking behaviour. 2 psychol. Compulsion to display one's genitals in public.
v. (often as exhilarating adj. Or exhilarated adj.) Enliven, gladden; raise the spirits of.
v. (often foll. By to + infin.) Urge strongly or earnestly.
v. (-ming) dig up (esp. A buried corpse).
n. (pl. -ies) (also exigence) 1 urgent need or demand. 2 emergency.
adj. Scanty, small.
n. 1 expulsion from one's native land or (internal exile) native town etc. 2 long absence abroad. 3 exiled person. v. (-ling) send into exile. [french from latin]
v. 1 have a place in objective reality. 2 (of circumstances etc.) Occur; be found. 3 live with no pleasure. 4 continue in being. 5 live. [latin existo]
n. 1 fact or manner of being or existing. 2 continuance in life or being. 3 all that exists.
adj. 1 of or relating to existence. 2 philos. Concerned with existence, esp. With human existence as viewed by existentialism.
n. Philosophical theory emphasizing the existence of the individual as a free and self-determining agent.

n. 1 passage or door by which to leave a room etc. 2 act or right of going out. 3 place where vehicles can leave a motorway etc. 4 actor's departure from the stage. v. (-t-) 1 go out of a room etc. 2 leave the stage (also as a direction: exit macbeth). [latin exeo exit- go out]
n. Poll of people leaving a polling-station, asking how they voted.
comb. Form external. [greek exo outside]
adj. (of a gland) secreting through a duct. [greek krino sift]
n. 1 mass departure. 2 (exodus) biblical departure of the israelites from egypt. [greek hodos way]
adv. & attrib. Adj. By virtue of one's office. [latin]
v. (-ting) (often foll. By from) free or declare free from blame etc.
adj. (of a price, demand, etc.) Grossly excessive. [latin: related to *orbit]
v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 expel (a supposed evil spirit) by prayers etc. 2 (often foll. By of) free (a person or place) in this way.
n. (pl. -s or -dia) introductory part, esp. Of a discourse or treatise. [latin exordior begin]
adj. 1 introduced from a foreign country; not native. 2 strange or unusual. n. Exotic person or thing.
n.pl. Strange or rare objects.
v. 1 increase in size or importance. 2 (often foll. By on) give a fuller account. 3 become more genial. 4 set or write out in full. 5 spread out flat.
n. Wide continuous area of land, space, etc.
adj. That can be expanded.
n. 1 expanding or being expanded. 2 enlargement of the scale or scope of a business.
n. Advocacy of expansion, esp. Of a state's territory.
adj. 1 able or tending to expand. 2 extensive. 3 (of a person etc.) Effusive, open.
n. & adj. Colloq. Expatriate. [abbreviation]
v. (-ting) (usu. Foll. By on, upon) speak or write at length.
adj. 1 living abroad. 2 exiled. n. Expatriate person. v. (-ting) 1 expel (a person) from his or her native country. 2 refl. Renounce one's citizenship.
v. 1 a regard as likely. B look for as appropriate or one's due (i expect cooperation). 2 colloq. Think, suppose.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 state of expectation. 2 prospect. 3 (foll. By of) prospective chance.
adj. 1 hopeful, expecting. 2 having an expectation. 3 pregnant.
n. 1 expecting or anticipation. 2 thing expected. 3 (foll. By of) probability of an event. 4 (in pl.) One's prospects of inheritance.
adj. Causing expectoration. n. Expectorant medicine.
v. (-ting) (also absol.) Cough or spit out (phlegm etc.).
adj. Advantageous; advisable on practical rather than moral grounds. n. Means of attaining an end; resource.
v. (-ting) 1 assist the progress of. 2 accomplish (business) quickly. [latin expedio from pes ped- foot]
n. 1 journey or voyage for a particular purpose, esp. Exploration. 2 people etc. Undertaking this. 3 speed. [latin: related to *expedite]
adj. Of or used in an expedition.
adj. Acting or done with speed and efficiency.
v. (-ll-) (often foll. By from) 1 deprive (a person) of membership etc. Of a school, society, etc. 2 force out, eject. 3 order or force to leave a building etc. [latin pello puls- drive]
v. Spend or use up (money, time, etc.). [latin pendo pens- weigh]
adj. That may be sacrificed or dispensed with; not worth preserving or saving.
n. 1 spending or using up. 2 thing (esp. Money) expended.
n. 1 cost incurred; payment of money. 2 (usu. In pl.) A costs incurred in doing a job etc. B amount paid to reimburse this. 3 thing on which money is spent.
n. List of an employee's expenses payable by the employer.
adj. Costing or charging much.

n. 1 observation of or practical acquaintance with facts or events. 2 knowledge or skill resulting from this. 3 event or activity participated in or observed (a rare experience). v. (-cing) 1 have experience of; undergo. 2 feel. [latin experior -pert- try]
adj. 1 having had much experience. 2 skilled from experience (experienced driver).
adj. Involving or based on experience.
n. Procedure adopted in the hope of success, or for testing a hypothesis etc., or to demonstrate a known fact. v. (often foll. By on, with) make an experiment.
adj. 1 based on or making use of experiment. 2 used in experiments.

adj. 1 (often foll. By at, in) having special knowledge of or skill in a subject. 2 (attrib.) Involving or resulting from this (expert advice). n. (often foll. By at, in) person with special knowledge or skill.
n. Expert skill, knowledge, or judgement. [french]
v. (-ting) pay the penalty for or make amends for (wrongdoing).
v. (-ring) 1 (of a period of time, validity, etc.) Come to an end. 2 cease to be valid. 3 die. 4 (also absol.) Breathe out (air etc.).
n. End of validity or duration.
v. 1 a make clear or intelligible (also absol.: let me explain). B make known in detail. 2 (foll. By that) say by way of explanation. 3 account for (one's conduct etc.).
n. 1 explaining. 2 statement or circumstance that explains something.
adj. Serving or designed to explain.
n. Swear-word or exclamation. [latin expleo fill out]
adj. That can be explained.
v. (-ting) 1 develop the meaning of (an idea etc.). 2 explain (esp. A literary text).
adj. 1 expressly stated, not merely implied; stated in detail. 2 definite. 3 outspoken.

v. (-ding) 1 a expand suddenly with a loud noise owing to a release of internal energy. B cause (a bomb etc.) To explode. 2 give vent suddenly to emotion, esp. Anger. 3 (of a population etc.) Increase suddenly or rapidly. 4 show (a theory etc.) To be false or baseless. 5 (as exploded adj.) (of a drawing etc.) Showing the components of a mechanism somewhat separated but in the normal relative positions. [latin explodo -plos- hiss off the stage]
n. Daring feat. v. 1 make use of (a resource etc.). 2 usu. Derog. Utilize or take advantage of (esp. A person) for one's own ends.
v. (-ring) 1 travel through (a country etc.) To learn about it. 2 inquire into. 3 surgery examine (a part of the body) in detail.
n. 1 exploding. 2 loud noise caused by this. 3 sudden outbreak of feeling. 4 rapid or sudden increase. [latin: related to *explode]
adj. 1 able, tending, likely to explode. 2 likely to cause a violent outburst etc.; dangerously tense. n. Explosive substance.
n. (also expo) (pl. -s) large international exhibition. [abbreviation of *exposition 4]

n. 1 person who promotes an idea etc. 2 practitioner of an activity, profession, etc. 3 person who explains or interprets something. 4 type or representative. 5 raised symbol beside a numeral indicating how many of the number are to be multiplied together (e.g. 23 = 2 x 2 x 2). [latin expono *expound]
adj. 1 of or indicated by a mathematical exponent. 2 (of an increase etc.) More and more rapid.
v. Sell or send (goods or services) to another country. n. 1 exporting. 2 a exported article or service. B (in pl.) Amount exported.

v. (-sing) (esp. As exposed adj.) 1 leave uncovered or unprotected, esp. From the weather. 2 (foll. By to) a put at risk of. B subject to (an influence etc.). 3 photog. Subject (a film) to light, esp. By operation of a camera. 4 reveal the identity or fact of. 5 exhibit, display.
n. 1 orderly statement of facts. 2 revelation of something discreditable. [french]
n. 1 explanatory account. 2 explanation or commentary. 3 mus. Part of a movement in which the principal themes are presented. 4 large public exhibition. [latin: related to *expound]
adj. & adv. With retrospective action or force. [latin, = in the light of subsequent events]
v. (-ting) (often foll. By with a person) make a protest; remonstrate.

n. (foll. By to) 1 exposing or being exposed. 2 physical condition resulting from being exposed to the elements. 3 photog. A exposing a film etc. To the light. B duration of this. C section of film etc. Affected by it.
v. 1 set out in detail. 2 explain or interpret. [latin pono posit- place]

v. 1 represent or make known in words or by gestures, conduct, etc. 2 refl. Communicate what one thinks, feels, or means. 3 esp. Math. Represent by symbols. 4 squeeze out (liquid or air). 5 send by express service. adj. 1 operating at high speed. 2 also definitely stated. 3 delivered by a specially fast service. adv. 1 at high speed. 2 by express messenger or train. n. 1 express train etc. 2 us service for the rapid transport of parcels etc.

n. 1 expressing or being expressed. 2 word or phrase expressed. 3 person's facial appearance, indicating feeling. 4 conveying of feeling in music, speaking, dance, etc. 5 depiction of feeling etc. In art. 6 math. Collection of symbols expressing a quantity.
n. Style of painting, music, drama, etc., seeking to express emotion rather than the external world.
adj. 1 full of expression (expressive look). 2 (foll. By of) serving to express.
var. Of *espresso.
n. Us motorway.
v. (-ting) 1 take away (property) from its owner. 2 (foll. By from) dispossess.
n. Expelling or being expelled.
v. (-ging) erase, remove (objectionable matter) from a book etc. [latin expungo prick out (for deletion)]
v. (-ting) 1 remove objectionable matter from (a book etc.). 2 remove (such matter).
adj. 1 extremely beautiful or delicate. 2 keenly felt (exquisite pleasure). 3 highly sensitive (exquisite taste).
n. Man formerly a member of the armed forces.
F
n. (also f) (pl. Fs or f's) 1 sixth letter of the alphabet. 2 mus. Fourth note of the diatonic scale of c major.
abbr. (also f.) 1 fahrenheit. 2 farad(s). 3 fine (pencil-lead).
symb. Fluorine.
abbr. (also f.) 1 female. 2 feminine. 3 following page etc. 4 mus. Forte. 5 folio. 6 focal length.
abbr. Football association.
var. Of *fah.
adj. Colloq. Fabulous, marvellous. [abbreviation]
n. 1 a fictional, esp. Supernatural, story. B moral tale, esp. With animals as characters. 2 legendary tales collectively (in fable). 3 a lie. B thing only supposed to exist. [latin fabula discourse]
adj. Celebrated; legendary.
n. 1 woven material; cloth. 2 walls, floor, and roof of a building. 3 essential structure. [latin faber metal-worker]
v. (-ting) 1 construct, esp. From components. 2 invent (a story etc.). 3 forge (a document).
adj. 1 incredible. 2 colloq. Marvellous. 3 legendary.
n. 1 face or front of a building. 2 outward appearance, esp. A deceptive one. [french: related to *face]

n. 1 front of the head from forehead to chin. 2 facial expression. 3 coolness, effrontery. 4 surface, esp.: a the side of a mountain etc. (north face). B = *coalface. C geom. Each surface of a solid. D the faade of a building. E the dial of a clock etc. 5 functional side of a tool etc. 6 = *typeface. 7 aspect (unacceptable face of capitalism). v. (-cing) 1 look or be positioned towards or in a certain direction. 2 be opposite. 3 meet resolutely. 4 confront (faces us with a problem). 5 a coat the surface of (a thing). B put a facing on (a garment).
n. Cloth for washing one's face.
n. = *face-cloth.
adj. 1 without identity; characterless. 2 purposely not identifiable.
n. 1 (also face-lifting) cosmetic surgery to remove wrinkles etc. 2 improvement to appearance, efficiency, etc.
n. Skin preparation for the face.
n. Colloq. Sudden difficulty.
n. 1 aspect. 2 side of a cut gem etc. [french: related to *fact]
adj. Intending or intended to be amusing, esp. Inappropriately.
adv. & adj. (also face-to-face when attrib.) (often foll. By with) facing; confronting each other.
n. 1 nominal value of money. 2 superficial appearance or implication.
var. Of *fascia.
adj. Of or for the face. n. Beauty treatment for the face.
adj. Usu. Derog. 1 easily achieved but of little value. 2 glib, fluent. [latin facio do]
v. (-ting) ease (a process etc.).
n. (pl. -ies) 1 ease; absence of difficulty. 2 fluency, dexterity. 3 (esp. In pl.) Opportunity or equipment for doing something. [latin: related to *facile]
n. 1 layer of material covering part of a garment etc. For contrast or strength. 2 outer covering on a wall etc.
n. Exact copy, esp. Of writing, printing, a picture, etc. [latin, = make like]
n. 1 thing that is known to exist or to be true. 2 (usu. In pl.) Item of verified information. 3 truth, reality. 4 thing assumed as the basis for argument.
n. Small organized dissentient group within a larger one, esp. In politics.
comb. Form forming nouns of action from verbs in -fy (satisfaction). [latin -factio]
adj. Of, characterized by, or inclined to faction. [latin: related to *faction]
adj. 1 specially contrived. 2 artificial. [latin: related to *fact]
n. Something that must be accepted.

n. 1 circumstance etc. Contributing to a result. 2 whole number etc. That when multiplied with another produces a given number. 3 a business agent. B scot. Land-agent, steward. C agent, deputy. [latin: related to *fact]
n. Product of a number and all the whole numbers below it. adj. Of a factor or factorial.
v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) resolve into factors.
n. (pl. -ies) building(s) in which goods are manufactured. [ultimately from latin factorium]
n. Farm using intensive or industrial methods of livestock rearing.
n. (pl. -s) employee who does all kinds of work. [medieval latin: related to *fact, *total]
n.pl. Precise details.
n. Information leaflet, esp. Accompanying a television programme.
n.pl. (prec. By the) information about sexual functions and practices.
adj. Based on or concerned with fact.

n. (pl. -ies) 1 aptitude for a particular activity. 2 inherent mental or physical power. 3 a group of related university departments. B us teaching staff of a university or college. 4 authorization, esp. By a church authority. [latin: related to *facile]
n. 1 craze. 2 peculiar notion.
adj. (-ier, -iest) having petty likes and dislikes.

v. (-ding) 1 lose or cause to lose colour, light, or sound; slowly diminish. 2 lose freshness or strength. 3 (foll. By in, out) cinematog. Etc. Cause (a picture or sound) to appear or disappear, increase or decrease, gradually. n. Action of fading.
n.pl. (us feces) waste matter discharged from the bowels.
v. Colloq. (often foll. By about, around) fuss, dither. [imitative]

n. 1 colloq. Tedious task. 2 slang cigarette. 3 (at public schools) junior boy who runs errands for a senior. v. (-gg-) 1 (often foll. By out) colloq. Exhaust. 2 (at public schools) act as a fag. [origin unknown]
n. Us slang offens. Male homosexual. [abbreviation of *faggot]
n. Slang cigarette-end.
n. (us fagot) 1
n. (brit. Faggot) 1
n. (also fa) mus. Fourth note of a major scale. [latin famuli: see *gamut]
