n. Andiron.
n. Fire-resistant door preventing the spread of fire.
n. Rehearsal of the procedures to be used in case of fire.
n. 1 conjuror who appears to swallow fire. 2 quarrelsome person.
n. Vehicle carrying hoses, firefighters, etc.
n. Emergency staircase etc. For use in a fire.
n. Apparatus discharging foam etc. To extinguish a fire.
n. = *fireman 1.
n. Beetle emitting phosphorescent light, e.g. The glow-worm.
n. Protective screen placed in front of a fireplace.
n.pl. Tongs, poker, and shovel for a domestic fire.
n. Light from a fire in a fireplace.
n. Inflammable material used to start a fire in a grate.
n. 1 member of a fire brigade. 2 person who tends a steam engine or steamship furnace.
n. 1 place for a domestic fire, esp. A recess in a wall. 2 structure surrounding this.
n. Destructive capacity of guns etc.
n. Fire-drill.
adj. Able to resist fire or great heat. v. Make fireproof.
n. Arsonist.
n. 1 ornamental screen for a fireplace. 2 screen against the direct heat of a fire. 3 fire-guard.
n. Hist. Ship set on fire and directed against an enemy's ships etc.
n. 1 area round a fireplace. 2 home or home-life.
n. Headquarters of a fire brigade.
n. High wind or storm following a fire caused by bombs.
n. Building without fire-escapes etc.
n. Person keeping watch for fires, esp. Those caused by bombs.
n. Colloq. Strong alcoholic liquor.
n. Wood as fuel.
n. 1 device that burns or explodes spectacularly when lit. 2 (in pl.) Outburst of passion, esp. Anger.
n. 1 discharge of guns. 2 fuel.
n. 1 front line in a battle. 2 centre of activity etc.
n. 1 soldiers ordered to shoot a condemned person. 2 group firing the salute at a military funeral.

adj. 1 a solid or compact. B fixed, stable, steady. 2 a resolute, determined. B steadfast, constant (firm belief; firm friend). 3 (of an offer etc.) Definite; not conditional. adv. Firmly (stand firm). v. (often foll. By up) make or become firm, secure, compact, or solid.
n. Business concern or its partners. [latin firma: cf. *firm1]
n. Literary the sky regarded as a vault or arch. [latin: related to *firm1]
n. Computing permanent kind of software.
see *fir.

adj. 1 earliest in time or order (took the first bus). 2 foremost in rank or importance (first lord of the treasury). 3 most willing or likely (the first to admit it). 4 basic or evident (first principles). n. 1 (prec. By the) person or thing first mentioned or occurring. 2 first occurrence of something notable. 3 place in the first class in an examination. 4 first gear. 5 a first place in a race. B winner of this. adv. 1 before any other person or thing (first of all; first and foremost). 2 before someone or something else (get this done first). 3 for the first time (when did you first see her?). 4 in preference; rather (will see him damned first).
n. Emergency medical treatment.
adj. Eldest. n. Person's eldest child.

n. 1 best group or category. 2 best accommodation in a train, ship, etc. 3 mail given priority. 4 highest division in an examination. adj. & adv. (first-class) 1 of or by the first class. 2 excellent.
see *cousin.
n. Envelope with stamps postmarked on their first day of issue.
adj. Denoting non-serious surface burns.
n. Finger next to the thumb.
n. (us second floor) floor above the ground floor.
scot. n. First person to cross a threshold in the new year. v. Be a first-foot.
n. (usu. In pl.) 1 first agricultural produce of a season, esp. As offered to god. 2 first results of work etc.
adj. & adv. From the original source; direct.
n. (in the us) wife of the president.
n. Dawn.
adv. In the first place, first (cf. *first adv.).
n. (on a merchant ship) second in command.
n. Personal or christian name.
n. First public performance of a play etc.
n. Criminal without previous convictions.
n. = *first mate.
see *person.
n. (also last post) bugle-call as a signal to retire for the night.
adj. 1 excellent. 2 colloq. Very well (feeling first-rate).
adv. Colloq. Before anything else; very early.
n. (also frith) 1 narrow inlet of sea. 2 estuary. [old norse: related to *fiord]
adj. Of public revenue. n. 1 legal official in some countries. 2 scot. = *procurator fiscal. [latin fiscus treasury]
n. = *financial year.

n. (pl. Same or -es) 1 vertebrate cold-blooded animal with gills and fins living wholly in water. 2 any of various non-vertebrate animals living wholly in water, e.g. The cuttlefish, shellfish, and jellyfish. 3 fish as food. 4 colloq. Person of a specified, usu. Unpleasant, kind (an odd fish). 5 (the fish or fishes) sign or constellation pisces. v. 1 try to catch fish. 2 fish in (a certain river, pool, etc.). 3 (foll. By for) a search for. B seek indirectly (fishing for compliments). 4 (foll. By up, out, etc.) Retrieve with effort.
n. Flat or curved plate of iron, wood, etc., used to strengthen a beam, joint, or mast. [french ficher fix, from latin figere *fix]
n. (usu. Round) glass bowl for pet fish.
n. Breaded cake of fish and mashed potato, usu. Fried.
n. 1 animal that catches fish. 2 archaic fisherman. [old english]
n. Man who catches fish as a livelihood or for sport.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 place where fish are caught or reared. 2 industry of fishing or breeding fish.
n. Very wide-angle lens with a highly-curved front.
n. Place where fish are bred for food.
n. Small oblong piece of fish in batter or breadcrumbs.
n. Barbed hook for catching fish.
n. Catching fish.
n. Thread with a baited hook etc. For catching fish.
n. Tapering usu. Jointed rod for fishing.
n. Oval pan for boiling fish.
n. Knife for eating or serving fish.
n. Ground dried fish as fertilizer or animal feed.
n. Dealer in fish.
n. (often attrib.) Open-meshed fabric (fishnet stockings).
n. Flat piece of iron etc. Connecting railway rails or positioning masonry.
n. Flat slotted cooking utensil.
n. Device etc. Shaped like a fish's tail.
n. 1 coarse-mannered or noisy woman. 2 woman who sells fish.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 of or like fish. 2 slang dubious, suspect.
adj. 1 capable of undergoing nuclear fission. 2 tending to split. [latin: related to *fissure]
n. 1 splitting of a heavy atomic nucleus, with a release of energy. 2 cell division as a mode of reproduction. v. (cause to) undergo fission.
n. Atomic bomb.
n. Crack or split, usu. Long and narrow. v. (-ring) split, crack. [latin findo fiss- cleave]
n. Tightly closed hand.
n.pl. Fighting with the fists. [probably from obsolete fisty (from *fist), *cuff2]
n. (pl. -s or -lae) abnormal or artificial passage between an organ and the body surface or between two organs.

adj. (fitter, fittest) 1 a well suited. B qualified, competent, worthy. C in suitable condition, ready. D (foll. By for) good enough (fit for a king). 2 in good health or condition. 3 proper, becoming, right (it is fit that). v. (-tt-) 1 a (also absol.) Be of the right shape and size for (dress fits her; key doesn't fit). B (often foll. By in, into) be correctly positioned (that bit fits here). C find room for (fit another on here). 2 make suitable or competent; adapt (fitted for battle). 3 (usu. Foll. By with) supply. 4 fix in place (fit a lock on the door). 5 = fit on. 6 befit, become (it fits the occasion). n. Way in which a garment, component, etc., fits (tight fit). adv. (foll. By to + infin.) Colloq. So that; likely (laughing fit to bust).
n. 1 sudden esp. Epileptic seizure with unconsciousness or convulsions. 2 sudden brief bout or burst (fit of giggles; fit of coughing).
adj. Spasmodic or intermittent.
n. (usu. In pl.) Fixed item of furniture.
adj. 1 made to fit closely or exactly (fitted carpet). 2 provided with built-in fittings etc. (fitted kitchen). 3 built-in (fitted cupboards).
n. 1 mechanic who fits together and adjusts machinery. 2 supervisor of the cutting, fitting, etc. Of garments.
n. 1 trying-on of a garment etc. For adjustment before completion. 2 (in pl.) Fixtures and fitments of a building. adj. Proper, becoming, right.
adj. & n. 1 one more than four. 2 symbol for this (5, v, v). 3 size etc. Denoted by five. 4 set or team of five. 5 five o'clock (is it five yet?). 6 cricket hit scoring five runs. [old english]
adj. & adv. 1 five times as much or as many. 2 consisting of five parts.
n. Beard-growth visible in the latter part of the day.
n. Colloq. Five-pound note.
n. Game in which a ball is hit with a gloved hand or bat against the walls of a court.
adj. Of the highest class.
n. Jacks played with five pieces of metal etc. And usu. No ball.

v. 1 make firm or stable; fasten, secure. 2 decide, settle, specify (a price, date, etc.). 3 mend, repair. 4 implant in the mind. 5 a (foll. By on, upon) direct (the eyes etc.) Steadily, set. B attract and hold (the attention, eyes, etc.). C (foll. By with) single out with one's look etc. 6 place definitely, establish. 7 determine the exact nature, position, etc., of; refer (a thing) to a definite place or time; identify, locate. 8 a make (the eyes, features, etc.) Rigid. B (of eyes, features, etc.) Become rigid. 9 us colloq. Prepare (food or drink). 10 congeal or become congealed. 11 colloq. Punish, kill, deal with (a person). 12 colloq. A bribe or threaten into supporting. B gain a fraudulent result of (a race etc.). 13 slang inject a narcotic. 14 make (a colour, photographic image, etc.) Fast or permanent. 15 (of a plant etc.) Assimilate (nitrogen or carbon dioxide). n. 1 colloq. Dilemma, predicament. 2 a finding one's position by bearings etc. B position found in this way. 3 slang dose of an addictive drug.
v. (-ting) 1 direct one's gaze on. 2 psychol. (usu. In passive; often foll. By on, upon) cause (a person) to become abnormally attached to a person or thing. [latin: related to *fix]
n. 1 state of being fixated. 2 obsession, monomania. 3 coagulation. 4 process of assimilating a gas to form a solid compound.
adj. Tending to fix or secure. n. Fixative substance.
adv. Intently.
n. Astron. Seemingly motionless star.
n. 1 person or thing that fixes. 2 photog. Substance for fixing a photographic image etc. 3 colloq. Person who makes esp. Illicit deals.
n.pl. Us 1 apparatus or equipment. 2 trimmings for a dish, dress, etc.
n. Fixed state; stability; permanence.

n. 1 a something fixed in position. B colloq. Seemingly immovable person or thing (seems to be a fixture). 2 a sporting event, esp. A match, race, etc. B date agreed for this. 3 (in pl.) Articles attached to a house or land and regarded as legally part of it.
v. 1 make a hissing or spluttering sound. 2 (of a drink) effervesce. n. 1 effervescence. 2 colloq. Effervescent drink, esp. Champagne. [imitative]
v. (-ling) make a feeble hiss. n. Such a sound.
adj. (-ier, -iest) effervescent.
var. Of *fiord.
Abbr. 1 floruit. 2 fluid.
n. Colloq. Fat; flabbiness. [imitative, or from *flabby]
v. (esp. As flabbergasted adj.) Colloq. Astonish; dumbfound. [origin uncertain]
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 (of flesh etc.) Limp; flaccid. 2 feeble.
adj. Limp, flabby, drooping.

n. 1 a usu. Oblong or square piece of cloth, attachable by one edge to a pole or rope as a country's emblem or standard, a signal, etc. B small toy etc. Resembling a flag. 2 adjustable strip of metal etc. Indicating a taxi's availability for hire. v. (-gg-) 1 a grow tired; lag (was soon flagging). B hang down; droop. 2 mark out with or as if with a flag or flags. 3 (often foll. By that) inform or communicate by flag-signals.
n. (also flagstone) 1 flat usu. Rectangular paving stone. 2 (in pl.) Pavement of these. v. (-gg-) pave with flags. [probably scandinavian]
n. Plant with a bladed leaf (esp. The iris). [origin unknown]
n. Fund-raising day for a charity, esp. With the sale of small paper flags etc. In the street.
n. Person who scourges himself, herself, or others as a religious discipline or as a sexual stimulus. adj. Of flagellation. [latin flagellum whip]
v. (-ting) scourge, flog.
n. (pl. -gella) 1 long lashlike appendage on some microscopic organisms. 2 runner; creeping shoot. [latin, = whip]
n. Small flute blown at the end. [french from provenal]
n. Foreign flag under which a ship is registered, usu. To avoid regulations or financial charges.
n. Admiral, vice admiral, or rear admiral, or the commodore of a yacht-club.
n. White flag requesting a truce.
n. 1 large bottle, usu. Holding a quart (1.13 litres), esp. Of wine, cider, etc. 2 large vessel for wine etc., usu. With a handle, spout, and lid. [latin flasco *flask]
n. = *flagstaff.
adj. Blatant; notorious; scandalous.
n. 1 ship with an admiral on board. 2 leader in a category etc.; exemplar.
n. Pole on which a flag may be hoisted.
n. = *flag2.
n. Populist agitation, chauvinism.
n. Wooden staff with a short heavy stick swinging from it, used for threshing. v. 1 wave or swing wildly. 2 beat with or as with a flail. [latin flagellum whip]
n. 1 natural talent in a specific area (flair for languages). 2 style, finesse. [french flairer to smell]
n. 1 anti-aircraft fire. 2 adverse criticism; abuse. [german, fliegerabwehrkanone, aviator-defence-gun]

n. 1 small thin light piece of snow etc. 2 thin broad piece peeled or split off. 3 dogfish etc. As food. v. (-king) (often foll. By away, off) 1 take off or come away in flakes. 2 sprinkle with or fall in flakes.
n. Protective reinforced military jacket.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 of, like, or in flakes. 2 esp. Us slang crazy, eccentric.
n. Crumblier version of puff pastry.
adj. (of food) covered with alcohol and set alight briefly (following a noun: pancakes flamb). [french: related to *flame]
adj. 1 ostentatious; showy. 2 floridly decorated or coloured.

n. 1 a ignited gas. B portion of this (flame flickered; burst into flames). 2 a bright light or colouring. B brilliant orange-red colour. 3 a strong passion, esp. Love (fan the flame). B colloq. Sweetheart. v. (-ming) 1 (often foll. By away, forth, out, up) burn; blaze. 2 (often foll. By out, up) a (of passion) break out. B (of a person) become angry. 3 shine or glow like flame. [latin flamma]
n. (pl. -s) 1 style of spanish gypsy guitar music with singing. 2 dance performed to this. [spanish, = flemish]
n. Weapon for throwing a spray of flame.
adj. 1 emitting flames. 2 very hot (flaming june). 3 colloq. A passionate (flaming row). B expressing annoyance (that flaming dog). 4 bright-coloured.
n. (pl. -s or -es) tall long-necked wading bird with mainly pink plumage. [provenal: related to *flame]
adj. Inflammable.
flammable is often used because inflammable can be mistaken for a negative (the true negative being non-flammable).
n. 1 pastry case with a savoury or sweet filling. 2 sponge base with a sweet topping. [medieval latin flado -onis]
n. Projecting flat rim etc., for strengthening or attachment. [origin uncertain]

n. 1 side of the body between ribs and hip. 2 side of a mountain, building, etc. 3 right or left side of an army etc. v. (often in passive) be at or move along the side of (road flanked by mountains). [french from germanic]

n. 1 a woven woollen usu. Napless fabric. B (in pl.) Flannel garments, esp. Trousers. 2 face-cloth, esp. Towelling. 3 slang nonsense; flattery. v. (-ll-; us -l-) 1 slang flatter. 2 wash with a flannel. [welsh gwlanen from gwlan wool]
n. Napped cotton fabric like flannel.

v. (-pp-) 1 move or be moved up and down; beat. 2 colloq. Be agitated or panicky. 3 sway; flutter. 4 (usu. Foll. By away, off) strike (flies etc.) With flat object; drive. 5 colloq. (of ears) listen intently. n. 1 piece of cloth, wood, etc. Attached by one side esp. To cover a gap, e.g. A pocket-cover, the folded part of an envelope, a table-leaf. 2 motion of a wing, arm, etc. 3 colloq. Agitation; panic (in a flap). 4 aileron. 5 light blow with something flat.
n. Colloq. Nonsense. [origin unknown]
n. 1 sweet oatcake. 2 esp. Us pancake.
n. 1 person apt to panic. 2 slang (in the 1920s) young unconventional woman.

v. (-ring) 1 widen gradually (flared trousers). 2 (cause to) blaze brightly and unsteadily. 3 burst out, esp. Angrily. n. 1 a dazzling irregular flame or light. B sudden outburst of flame. 2 flame or bright light used as a signal or to illuminate a target etc. 3 a gradual widening, esp. Of a skirt or trousers. B (in pl.) Wide-bottomed trousers.
n. Line of lights on a runway to guide aircraft.
n. Sudden outburst.

v. 1 (cause to) emit a brief or sudden light; (cause to) gleam. 2 send or reflect like a sudden flame (eyes flashed fire). 3 a burst suddenly into view or perception (answer flashed upon me). B move swiftly (train flashed past). 4 a send (news etc.) By radio, telegraph, etc. B signal to (a person) with lights. 5 colloq. Show ostentatiously (flashed her ring). 6 slang indecently expose oneself. n. 1 sudden bright light or flame, e.g. Of lightning. 2 an instant (in a flash). 3 sudden brief feeling, display of wit, etc. (flash of hope). 4 = *newsflash. 5 photog. = *flashlight 1. 6 mil. Coloured cloth patch on a uniform. 7 bright patch of colour. adj. Colloq. Gaudy; showy; vulgar (flash car). [imitative]
n. Scene set in an earlier time than the main action.
n. Photog. Bulb for a flashlight.
n. Photog. Set of four flash bulbs in a cube, operated in turn.
n. 1 slang man who indecently exposes himself. 2 automatic device for switching lights rapidly on and off.
n. Device operating a camera flashlight.
n. (usu. Metal) strip used to prevent water penetration at a roof joint etc. [dial.]
n. Promising start followed by failure.
n. Portable flashing electric lamp.
n. 1 light giving an intense flash, used for night or indoor photography. 2 us electric torch.
n. 1 temperature at which vapour from oil etc. Will ignite in air. 2 point at which anger etc. Is expressed.
adj. (-ier, -iest) showy; gaudy; cheaply attractive.
n. 1 narrow-necked bulbous bottle for wine etc. Or used in chemistry. 2 = *hip-flask. 3 = *vacuum flask. [latin flasca, flasco: cf. *flagon]

adj. (flatter, flattest) 1 a horizontally level. B even; smooth; unbroken. C level and shallow (flat cap). 2 unqualified; downright (flat refusal). 3 a dull; lifeless; monotonous (in a flat tone). B dejected. 4 (of a fizzy drink) having lost its effervescence. 5 (of an accumulator, battery, etc.) Having exhausted its charge. 6 mus. A below true or normal pitch (violins are flat). B (of a key) having a flat or flats in the signature. C (as b, e, etc. Flat) semitone lower than b, e, etc. 7 (of a tyre) punctured; deflated. adv. 1 at full length; spread out (lay flat; flat against the wall). 2 colloq. A completely, absolutely (flat broke). B exactly (in five minutes flat). 3 mus. Below the true or normal pitch (sings flat). n. 1 flat part or thing (flat of the hand). 2 level ground, esp. A plain or swamp. 3 mus. A note lowered a semitone below natural pitch. B sign indicating this. 4 (as the flat) flat racing or its season. 5 theatr. Flat scenery on a frame. 6 esp. Us colloq. Flat tyre.
n. Set of rooms, usu. On one floor, as a residence.
n. Sole, plaice, etc. With both eyes on one side of a flattened body.
n. Foot with a flattened arch.
n. 1 having flat feet. 2 colloq. A uninspired. B unprepared. C resolute.
n. Hist. Domestic iron heated on a fire etc.
n. Person sharing a flat.
n. Horse race without jumps, over level ground.
n. Unvarying rate or charge.
n. 1 aeron. A nearly horizontal spin. 2 colloq. State of panic.
v. 1 make or become flat. 2 colloq. A humiliate. B knock down.

v. 1 compliment unduly, esp. For gain or advantage. 2 (usu. Refl.; usu. Foll. By that) congratulate or delude (oneself etc.) (he flatters himself that he can sing). 3 (of colour, style, portrait, painter etc.) Enhance the appearance of (that blouse flatters you). 4 cause to feel honoured.
n. Exaggerated or insincere praise.
adj. 1 a causing intestinal wind. B caused by or suffering from this. 2 (of speech etc.) Inflated, pretentious.
n. Worm with a flattened body, e.g. Flukes.
v. (often refl.) Display proudly; show off; parade. [origin unknown]
flaunt is often confused with flout which means to disobey contemptuously.
n. Flute-player. [italian: related to *flute]

(brit. Flavour) n. 1 mingled sensation of smell and taste (cheesy flavour). 2 characteristic quality (romantic flavour). 3 (usu. Foll. By of) slight admixture (flavour of failure). v. Give flavour to; season.
n. (brit. Flavouring) substance used to flavour food or drink.

(us flavor) n. 1 mingled sensation of smell and taste (cheesy flavour). 2 characteristic quality (romantic flavour). 3 (usu. Foll. By of) slight admixture (flavour of failure). v. Give flavour to; season.
n. (us flavoring) substance used to flavour food or drink.
n. (also flavour of the week) temporary trend or fashion.
n. 1 imperfection; blemish. 2 crack, chip, etc. 3 invalidating defect. v. Crack; damage; spoil.
n. Squall of wind. [low german or dutch]
n. 1 blue-flowered plant cultivated for its textile fibre and its seeds. 2 flax fibres. [old english]
adj. 1 of flax. 2 (of hair) pale yellow.
n. Linseed.
v. 1 strip the skin or hide off, esp. By beating. 2 criticize severely. 3 peel off (skin, bark, peel, etc.). 4 extort money etc. From. [old english]
n. Small wingless jumping parasitic insect.
n. Slang shabby or unattractive person or thing.
n. 1 bite of a flea. 2 trivial injury or inconvenience.
adj. 1 bitten by or infested with fleas. 2 shabby.
n. Street market selling second-hand goods etc.
n. Dingy dirty cinema etc.
n. 1 small patch of colour or light. 2 particle, speck. v. Mark with flecks. [old norse, or low german or dutch]
n. (brit. Flexion) 1 bending or being bent, esp. Of a limb or joint. 2 bent part; curve. [latin flexio: related to *flex1]
past and past part. Of *flee.
v. (-ging) 1 provide or deck (an arrow etc.) With feathers. 2 bring up (a young bird) until it can fly. 3 (as fledged adj.) A able to fly. B independent; mature. [obsolete adj. Fledge fit to fly]
n. (also fledgeling) 1 young bird. 2 inexperienced person.
v. (past and past part. Fled) 1 (often foll. By from, before) a run away (from); leave abruptly (fled the room). B seek safety by fleeing. 2 vanish. [old english]

n. 1 a woolly coat of a sheep etc. B wool sheared from a sheep at one time. 2 thing resembling a fleece, esp. Soft fabric for lining etc. v. (-cing) 1 (often foll. By of) strip of money, valuables, etc.; swindle. 2 shear (sheep etc.). 3 cover as if with a fleece (sky fleeced with clouds).
n. 1 a warships under one commander-in-chief. B (prec. By the) nation's warships etc.; navy. 2 number of vehicles in one company etc. adj. Poet. Literary swift, nimble. [old english]
adj. Transitory; brief.
n. 1 native of medieval flanders. 2 member of a flemish-speaking people of n. And w. Belgium. [old english]
adj. Of flanders. n. Language of the flemings. [dutch]

n. 1 a soft, esp. Muscular, substance between the skin and bones of an animal or a human. B plumpness; fat. 2 the body, esp. As sinful. 3 pulpy substance of a fruit etc. 4 a visible surface of the human body. B (also flesh-colour) yellowish pink colour. 5 animal or human life.
n. 1 the body or its substance. 2 humankind. 3 human nature, esp. As fallible. adj. Real, not imaginary.
adj. (-lier, -liest) 1 bodily; sensual. 2 mortal. 3 worldly.
n.pl. Luxurious living.
n. Superficial wound.
adj. (-ier, -iest) of flesh; plump, pulpy.
n. (also fleur-de-lys) (pl. Fleurs- pronunc. Same) 1 iris flower. 2 heraldry a lily of three petals. B former royal arms of france. [french, = flower of lily]
past of *fly1.
n.pl. Hanging lips of a bloodhound etc. [origin unknown]
v. 1 bend (a joint, limb, etc.) Or be bent. 2 move (a muscle) or (of a muscle) be moved to bend a joint. [latin flecto flex- bend]
n. Flexible insulated electric cable. [abbreviation of *flexible]
adj. 1 capable of bending without breaking; pliable. 2 manageable. 3 adaptable; variable (works flexible hours).
n. (us flection) 1 bending or being bent, esp. Of a limb or joint. 2 bent part; curve. [latin flexio: related to *flex1]
n. System of flexible working hours. [from *flexible]
n. Gossiping, frivolous, or restless person. [imitative]

n. 1 a light sharp blow with a whip etc. B sudden release of a bent digit, esp. To propel a small object. 2 sudden movement or jerk, esp. Of the wrist in throwing etc. 3 colloq. A cinema film. B (in pl.; prec. By the) the cinema. v. 1 (often foll. By away, off) strike or move with a flick (flicked the ash off). 2 give a flick with (a whip etc.).
v. 1 (of light or flame) shine or burn unsteadily. 2 flutter. 3 (of hope etc.) Waver. n. 1 flickering movement or light. 2 brief spell (of hope etc.).
n. Knife with a blade that springs out when a button is pressed.
var. Of *flyer.

n. 1 a act or manner of flying. B movement or passage through the air. 2 a journey through the air or in space. B timetabled airline journey. 3 flock of birds, insects, etc. 4 (usu. Foll. By of) series, esp. Of stairs. 5 imaginative excursion or sally (flight of fancy). 6 (usu. Foll. By of) volley (flight of arrows). 7 tail of a dart. [old english: related to *fly1]
n. Fleeing, hasty retreat.
n. Small zipped shoulder bag for air travel.
n. 1 deck of an aircraft-carrier. 2 control room of a large aircraft.
adj. (of a bird etc.) Unable to fly.
n. Raf officer next below squadron leader.
n. Planned course of an aircraft etc.
n. Device in an aircraft recording technical details of a flight.
n. Raf rank next above sergeant.
adj. (-ier, -iest) (usu. Of a girl) frivolous, fickle, changeable.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 insubstantial, rickety (flimsy structure). 2 (of an excuse etc.) Unconvincing. 3 (of clothing) thin.
v. Draw back in fear etc.; wince. [french from germanic]

v. (past and past part. Flung) 1 throw or hurl forcefully or hurriedly. 2 (foll. By on, off) put on or take off (clothes) carelessly or rapidly. 3 put or send suddenly or violently (was flung into jail). 4 rush, esp. Angrily (flung out of the room). 5 (foll. By away) discard rashly. n. 1 act of flinging; throw. 2 bout of wild behaviour. 3 whirling scottish dance, esp. The highland fling. [old norse]
n. 1 a hard grey siliceous stone. B piece of this, esp. As a primitive tool or weapon. 2 piece of hard alloy used to give a spark. 3 anything hard and unyielding.
n. Hist. Old type of gun fired by a spark from a flint.

v. (-pp-) 1 flick or toss (a coin, pellet, etc.) So that it spins in the air. 2 turn (a small object) over; flick. 3 slang = flip one's lid. n. 1 act of flipping. 2 colloq. Short trip. adj. Colloq. Glib; flippant.
n. 1 = *egg-flip. 2 drink of heated beer and spirit. [perhaps from *flip1]
n. Large pad of paper on a stand.
n. (usu. Rubber) sandal with a thong between the toes. [imitative]
adj. Frivolous; disrespectful; offhand.
n. 1 broad flat limb of a turtle, penguin, etc., used in swimming. 2 similar rubber foot attachment for underwater swimming. 3 slang hand.
adj. & adv. Slang expressing annoyance, or as an intensifier.
n. Colloq. 1 reverse side of a gramophone record. 2 reverse or less important side of something.
v. 1 (usu. Foll. By with) try to attract sexually but without serious intent. 2 (usu. Foll. By with) superficially engage in; trifle. n. Person who flirts.
v. (-tt-) 1 move lightly, softly, or rapidly. 2 make short flights. 3 colloq. Disappear secretly to escape creditors etc. n. Act of flitting. [old norse: related to *fleet]
n. Side of bacon. [old english]
v. Flit about; flutter. [from *flit]
n. = *bat2.

v. 1 a (cause to) rest or move on the surface of a liquid. B set (a stranded ship) afloat. 2 colloq. A move in a leisurely way. B (often foll. By before) hover before the eye or mind. 3 (often foll. By in) move or be suspended freely in a liquid or gas. 4 a start or launch (a company, scheme, etc.). B offer (stock, shares, etc.) On the stock market. 5 commerce cause or allow to have a fluctuating exchange rate. 6 circulate or cause (a rumour or idea) to circulate. n. 1 thing that floats, esp.: a a raft. B a light object as an indicator of a fish biting or supporting a fishing-net. C a hollow structure enabling an aircraft to float on water. D a floating device on water, petrol, etc., controlling the level. 2 small esp. Electrically-powered vehicle or cart (milk float). 3 decorated platform or tableau on a lorry in a procession etc. 4 a supply of loose change in a shop, at a fte, etc. B petty cash. 5 theatr. (in sing. Or pl.) Footlights. 6 tool for smoothing plaster.
var. Of *flotation.
adj. Not settled; variable (floating population).
n. Floating structure usable as a dry dock.
n. Abnormally movable kidney.
n. Lower rib not attached to the breastbone.
n. Voter without fixed allegiance.
adj. (esp. Of fabric) light and airy. [from *float]
adj. Like or in tufts of wool etc.; downy.
n. 1 animals of one kind as a group or unit. 2 large crowd of people. 3 people in the care of a priest or teacher etc. v. (usu. Foll. By to, in, out, together) congregate; mass; troop. [old english]
n. 1 lock or tuft of wool, cotton, etc. 2 (also in pl.; often attrib.) Wool-refuse etc. Used for quilting and stuffing. [latin floccus]
n. (also flock-wallpaper) wallpaper with a raised flock pattern.
n. Sheet of floating ice. [norwegian]
v. (-gg-) 1 a beat with a whip, stick, etc. B make work through violent effort (flogged the engine). 2 (often foll. By off) slang sell.
n. 1 a overflowing or influx of water, esp. Over land; inundation. B the water that overflows. 2 outpouring; torrent (flood of tears). 3 inflow of the tide (also in comb.: flood-tide).
n. 1 gate for admitting or excluding water, esp. In a lock. 2 (usu. In pl.) Last restraint against tears, rain, anger, etc.
n. Large powerful light (usu. One of several) to illuminate a building, sports ground, etc. v. Illuminate with floodlights.
n. Exceptionally high tide caused esp. By the moon.

n. 1 lower supporting surface of a room. 2 a bottom of the sea, a cave, etc. B any level area. 3 all the rooms etc. On one level of a building; storey. 4 a (in a legislative assembly) place where members sit and speak. B right to speak next in a debate (gave him the floor). 5 minimum of prices, wages, etc. 6 colloq. Ground. v. 1 provide with a floor; pave. 2 knock or bring (a person) down. 3 colloq. Confound, baffle. 4 colloq. Overcome. 5 serve as the floor of (lino floored the hall).
n. Long wooden board used for flooring.
n. Cloth for washing the floor.
n. Material of which a floor is made.
n. Stage-manager of a television production.
n. Diagram of the rooms etc. On one storey.
n. Nightclub entertainment.
n. (also floozy) (pl. -ies) colloq. Esp. Disreputable girl or woman. [origin unknown]

v. (-pp-) 1 sway about heavily or loosely. 2 (often foll. By down, on, into) fall or sit etc. Awkwardly or suddenly. 3 slang fail; collapse (play flopped). 4 make a dull soft thud or splash. n. 1 flopping movement or sound. 2 slang failure. adv. With a flop. [var. Of *flap]
adj. (-ier, -iest) tending to flop; flaccid. n. (pl. -ies) (in full floppy disk) computing flexible disc for the storage of data.
n. (pl. -s or florae) 1 plant life of a region or period. 2 list or book of these. [latin flora, name of the goddess of flowers]
adj. Of, decorated with, or depicting flowers.
adj. Of florence in italy. n. Native or citizen of florence. [latin]
n. 1 each of the small flowers making up a composite flower-head. 2 each stem of a head of cauliflower, broccoli, etc. 3 small flower. [latin flos *flower]
n. Plant, esp. A rose, bearing dense clusters of flowers. [related to *floret: cf. *moribund]
adj. 1 ruddy (florid complexion). 2 elaborately ornate; showy.
n. Hist. 1 british two-shilling coin now worth 10 pence. 2 english or foreign gold or silver coin. [italian fiorino: related to *florist]
n. Person who deals in or grows flowers. [latin flos *flower]
v. Flourished; lived and worked (of a painter, writer, etc., whose exact dates are unknown). n. Period or date of working etc. [latin, = he or she flourished]
n. 1 rough silk of a silkworm's cocoon. 2 silk thread used in embroidery. 3 = *dental floss. v. (also absol.) Clean (teeth) with dental floss.
n. (also floatation) launching or financing of a commercial enterprise etc. [from *float]
n. 1 small fleet. 2 fleet of small ships. [spanish]
n. Wreckage found floating. [anglo-french: related to *float]
n. 1 odds and ends. 2 vagrants.
v. (-cing) (often foll. By away, about, off, out) go or move angrily or impatiently (flounced out in a huff). n. Flouncing movement. [origin unknown]
n. Frill on a dress, skirt, etc. v. (-cing) trim with flounces. [alteration of frounce pleat, from french]
v. 1 struggle helplessly as if wading in mud. 2 do a task clumsily. n. Act of floundering. [imitative]
n. (pl. Same) 1 edible european flat-fish. 2 n. American flat-fish. [anglo-french, probably scandinavian]
n. 1 meal or powder from ground wheat etc. 2 any fine powder. v. Sprinkle with flour.

v. 1 a grow vigorously; thrive. B prosper. C be in one's prime. 2 wave, brandish. n. 1 showy gesture. 2 ornamental curve in handwriting. 3 mus. Ornate passage or fanfare. [latin floreo from flos *flower]
v. Disobey (the law etc.) Contemptuously; mock; insult. n. Flouting speech or act. [dutch fluiten whistle: related to *flute]
flout is often confused with flaunt which means to display proudly, show off.

v. 1 glide along as a stream. 2 (of liquid, blood, etc.) Gush out; be spilt. 3 (of blood, money, electric current, etc.) Circulate. 4 move smoothly or steadily. 5 (of a garment, hair, etc.) Hang gracefully. 6 (often foll. By from) be caused by. 7 (esp. Of the tide) be in flood. 8 (of wine) be plentiful. 9 (foll. By with) archaic be plentifully supplied with (flowing with milk and honey). n. 1 a flowing movement or mass. B flowing liquid (stop the flow). C outpouring; stream (flow of complaints). 2 rise of a tide or river (ebb and flow). [old english]
n. (also flow diagram or flow sheet) diagram of the movement or action in a complex activity.

n. 1 part of a plant from which the fruit or seed is developed. 2 blossom, esp. Used for decoration. 3 plant cultivated for its flowers. v. 1 bloom or cause (a plant) to bloom; blossom. 2 reach a peak.
n. Garden bed for flowers.
n. = *head n. 3 c.
n. Hippies with flowers as symbols of peace and love.
n. Pot for growing a plant in.
n. Peace and love, esp. As a political idea.
n. Fine powder produced when sulphur evaporates and condenses.
adj. 1 florally decorated. 2 (of style, speech, etc.) High-flown; ornate. 3 full of flowers.
adj. 1 (of style etc.) Fluent; easy. 2 (of a line, curve, etc.) Smoothly continuous. 3 (of hair etc.) Unconfined.
past part. Of *fly1.
n. Colloq. Influenza. [abbreviation]
v. (-ting) vary irregularly; rise and fall.
n. 1 smoke-duct in a chimney. 2 channel for conveying heat. [origin unknown]
adj. 1 (of speech, style, etc.) Flowing, natural. 2 verbally facile, esp. In a foreign language (fluent in german).
n. 1 soft fur, feathers, or fabric particles etc. 2 slang mistake in a performance etc. v. 1 (often foll. By up) shake into or become a soft mass. 2 colloq. Make a fluff; bungle.
n. Valved brass wind instrument like a cornet. [german flgel wing, horn horn]
n. 1 substance, esp. A gas or liquid, whose shape is determined by its confines. 2 fluid part or secretion. adj. 1 able to flow and alter shape freely. 2 constantly changing (situation is fluid).
n. One-twentieth, or us one-sixteenth, of a pint.
n. Lucky accident (won by a fluke). v. (-king) achieve by a fluke.
n. 1 parasitic flatworm, e.g. The liver fluke. 2 flat-fish, esp. A flounder. [old english]
n. 1 broad triangular plate on an anchor arm. 2 lobe of a whale's tail. [perhaps from *fluke2]
n. (pl. -ies) 1 flattery; nonsense. 2 sweet dish made with beaten eggs, sugar, etc. [welsh llymru]
v. Colloq. Bewilder, disconcert. [origin unknown]
past and past part. Of *fling.
v. Us colloq. Fail (esp. An exam). [origin unknown]
n. (also flunky) (pl. -eys or -ies) usu. Derog. 1 liveried footman. 2 toady; snob. 3 us cook, waiter, etc. [origin uncertain]
v. (-scing) be or become fluorescent. [from *fluorescent]
n. 1 light radiation from certain substances. 2 property of absorbing invisible light and emitting visible light. [from *fluorspar, after opalescence]
adj. Of, having, or showing fluorescence.
n. (also fluorescent bulb) esp. Tubular lamp or bulb radiating largely by fluorescence.
v. (-ting) add fluoride to (drinking-water etc.), esp. To prevent tooth decay.
n. Binary compound of fluorine.
v. (-ting) 1 = *fluoridate. 2 introduce fluorine into (a compound).
n. Poisonous pale-yellow gaseous element. [french: related to *fluorspar]
n. Mineral form of calcium fluoride. [italian: related to *fluorspar]
n. Compound of a hydrocarbon with fluorine atoms.
n. = *fluorite. [fluor a mineral used as flux, from latin fluo flow]
n. (pl. -ies) 1 gust or squall (of snow, rain, etc.). 2 sudden burst of activity, excitement, etc.; commotion. v. (-ies, -ied) confuse; agitate. [imitative]

v. 1 blush, redden, glow warmly (he flushed with embarrassment). 2 (usu. As flushed adj.) Cause to glow or blush (often foll. By with: he was flushed with pride). 3 a cleanse (a drain, lavatory, etc.) By a flow of water. B (often foll. By away, down) dispose of in this way. 4 rush out, spurt. n. 1 blush or glow. 2 a rush of water. B cleansing of a drain, lavatory, etc. Thus. 3 rush of esp. Elation or triumph. 4 freshness; vigour. 5 a (also hot flush) sudden feeling of heat during menopause. B feverish redness or temperature etc. adj. 1 level, in the same plane. 2 colloq. Having plenty of money. [perhaps = *flush3]
n. Hand of cards all of one suit, esp. In poker. [latin fluxus *flux]
v. 1 cause (esp. A game-bird) to fly up. 2 (of a bird) fly up and away.
v. 1 make or become nervous or confused (he flusters easily). 2 bustle. n. Confused or agitated state. [origin unknown]

n. 1 a high-pitched woodwind instrument held sideways. B any similar wind instrument. 2 ornamental vertical groove in a column. v. (-ting) 1 play, or play (a tune etc.) On, the flute. 2 speak or sing etc. In a high voice. 3 make grooves in.

v. 1 flap (the wings) in flying or trying to fly. 2 fall quiveringly (fluttered to the ground). 3 wave or flap quickly. 4 move about restlessly. 5 (of a pulse etc.) Beat feebly or irregularly. n. 1 act of fluttering. 2 tremulous excitement (caused a flutter). 3 slang small bet, esp. On a horse. 4 abnormally rapid heartbeat. 5 rapid variation of pitch, esp. Of recorded sound. [old english]
adj. Of or found in rivers. [latin fluvius river]
n. 1 process of flowing or flowing out. 2 discharge. 3 continuous change (state of flux). 4 substance mixed with a metal etc. To aid fusion. [latin fluxus from fluo flux- flow]

v. (flies; past flew; past part. Flown) 1 a (of an aircraft, bird, etc.) Move through the air or space under control, esp. With wings. B travel through the air or space. 2 control the flight of or transport in (esp. An aircraft). 3 a cause to fly or remain aloft. B (of a flag, hair, etc.) Wave or flutter. 4 pass, move, or rise quickly. 5 a flee; flee from. B colloq. Depart hastily. 6 be driven, forced, or scattered (sent me flying). 7 (foll. By at, upon) a hasten or spring violently. B attack or criticize fiercely. n. (pl. -ies) 1 (usu. In pl.) A concealing flap, esp. Over a trouser-fastening. B this fastening. 2 flap at a tent entrance. 3 (in pl.) Space above a stage where scenery and lighting are suspended. 4 act of flying.
n. (pl. Flies) 1 insect with two usu. Transparent wings. 2 other winged insect, e.g. A firefly. 3 disease of plants or animals caused by flies. 4 (esp. Artificial) fly as bait in fishing.
adj. Slang knowing, clever, alert. [origin unknown]
adj. (of hair) fine and difficult to control.
adj. Tainted, esp. By flies.
adj. Unreliable. n. Unreliable person.
n. Bird catching insects during short flights from a chosen perch.
n. (also flier) colloq. 1 airman or airwoman. 2 thing that flies in a specified way (poor flyer). 3 fast-moving animal or vehicle. 4 ambitious or outstanding person. 5 small handbill.
v. Fish with a fly.
n. Rugby stand-off half.
adj. 1 fluttering, waving, or hanging loose. 2 hasty, brief (flying visit). 3 designed for rapid movement. 4 (of an animal) leaping with winglike membranes etc. n. Flight, esp. In an aircraft.
n. Boatlike seaplane.
n. (usu. Arched) buttress running from the upper part of a wall to an outer support and transmitting the thrust of the roof or vault.
n. Doctor who uses an aircraft to visit patients.
n. Tropical fish with winglike fins for gliding through the air.
n. Fruit-eating bat with a foxlike head.
n. Raf rank next below flight lieutenant.
n. Mobile industrial strike picket.
n. Supposed alien spaceship.
n. Rapidly mobile police detachment etc.
n. 1 start (of a race etc.) In which the starting-point is crossed at full speed. 2 vigorous start (of an enterprise etc.).
n. Minor irritation or setback.
n. Blank leaf at the beginning or end of a book.
n. Unnoticed observer.
n. Bridge carrying one road or railway over another.
n. Sticky treated paper for catching flies.
n. Ceremonial flight of aircraft.
v. Fix (posters etc.) Illegally on walls etc.
n. 1 canvas cover over a tent for extra protection. 2 short tract or circular.
v. Illegally dump (waste).
n. Plant that catches flies.
n. 1 weight in certain sports between light flyweight and bantamweight, in amateur boxing 4851 kg. 2 sportsman of this weight.
n. Heavy wheel on a revolving shaft to regulate machinery or accumulate power.
abbr. 1 field marshal. 2 frequency modulation.
symb. Fermium.
n. Ratio of the focal length to the effective diameter of a camera lens. [from focal]
abbr. Flying officer.
n. Young of a horse or related animal. v. Give birth to (a foal).

n. 1 mass of small bubbles formed on or in liquid by agitation, fermentation, etc. 2 froth of saliva or sweat. 3 substance resembling these, e.g. Spongy rubber or plastic. v. Emit or run with foam; froth.
n. 1 chain of a pocket-watch. 2 small pocket for a watch etc. 3 tab on a key-ring. [german]
adj. Of or at a focus. [latin: related to *focus]
n. (also focal length) distance between the centre of a mirror or lens and its focus.
n. 1 = *focus n. 1. 2 centre of interest or activity.
var. Of *forecastle.

n. (pl. Focuses or foci) 1 a point at which rays or waves meet after reflection or refraction. B point from which rays etc. Appear to proceed. 2 a point at which an object must be situated for a lens or mirror to give a well-defined image. B adjustment of the eye or a lens to give a clear image. C state of clear definition (out of focus). 3 = *focal point 2. v. (-s- or -ss-) 1 bring into focus. 2 adjust the focus of (a lens or eye). 3 concentrate or be concentrated on. 4 converge or make converge to a focus. [latin, = hearth]
n. Dried hay or straw etc. As animal food. [old english]
abbr. Friends of the earth.
n. Esp. Poet. Enemy. [old english]
var. Of *fetid.
n. (us fetus) (pl. -tuses) unborn mammalian offspring, esp. A human embryo of eight weeks or more.

n. 1 thick cloud of water droplets or smoke suspended at or near the earth's surface. 2 cloudiness on a photographic negative etc. 3 uncertain or confused position or state. v. (-gg-) 1 cover or become covered with or as with fog. 2 perplex. [perhaps a back-formation from *foggy]
n. Mass of fog at sea.
adj. Unable to travel because of fog.
var. Of *fogy.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 full of fog. 2 of or like fog. 3 vague, indistinct.
n. 1 horn warning ships in fog. 2 colloq. Loud penetrating voice.
n. Powerful lamp for use in fog.
n. (also fogey) (pl. -ies or -eys) dull old-fashioned person (esp. Old fogy). [origin unknown]
n. Minor weakness or idiosyncrasy. [french: related to *feeble]
v. Frustrate, baffle, defeat. [perhaps from french fouler trample]
n. 1 metal rolled into a very thin sheet. 2 person or thing setting off another to advantage. [latin folium leaf]
n. Light blunt fencing sword. [origin unknown]
v. (foll. By on) force (a thing or oneself) on to an unwilling person. [dutch vuisten take in the hand]

v. 1 a bend or close (a flexible thing) over upon itself. B (foll. By back, over, down) bend part of (a thing) (fold down the flap). 2 become or be able to be folded. 3 (foll. By away, up) make compact by folding. 4 (often foll. By up) colloq. Collapse, cease to function. 5 enfold (esp. Fold in the arms or to the breast). 6 (foll. By about, round) clasp (the arms). 7 (foll. By in) mix (an ingredient with others) gently. n. 1 folding. 2 line made by folding. 3 folded part. 4 hollow among hills. 5 curvature of geological strata.
n. 1 = *sheepfold. 2 religious group or congregation. v. Enclose (sheep) in a fold. [old english]
suffix forming adjectives and adverbs from cardinal numbers, meaning: 1 in an amount multiplied by (repaid tenfold). 2 with so many parts (threefold blessing). [originally = folded in so many layers]
n. Folding cover or holder for loose papers.
adj. 1 of or like leaves. 2 laminated. [latin: related to *foil2]
n. Leaves, leafage. [french feuillage from feuille leaf]
adj. Of leaves. [as *foliate]
n. Fertilizer supplied to the leaves of plants.
adj. 1 leaflike. 2 having leaves. v. (-ting) split or beat into thin layers.

n. (pl. -s) 1 leaf of paper etc., esp. Numbered only on the front. 2 sheet of paper folded once making two leaves of a book. 3 book of such sheets. adj. (of a book) made of folios, of the largest size.

n. (pl. Same or -s) 1 (treated as pl.) People in general or of a specified class (few folk about; townsfolk). 2 (in pl.) (usu. Folks) one's parents or relatives. 3 (treated as sing.) A people or nation. 4 (in full folk-music) (treated as sing.) Colloq. Traditional music or modern music in this style. 5 (attrib.) Of popular origin (folk art). [old english]
n. Dance of popular origin.
n. Traditional beliefs and stories of a people; the study of these.
n. Singer of folk-songs.
n. Song of popular or traditional origin or style.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 of or like folk art, culture, etc. 2 friendly, unpretentious.
n. Traditional story.
n. Rough loosely woven fabric.
n. Small sac or vesicle in the body, esp. One containing a hair-root.

v. 1 (often foll. By after) go or come after (a person or thing ahead). 2 go along (a road etc.). 3 come after in order or time (dessert followed; proceed as follows). 4 take as a guide or leader. 5 conform to. 6 practise (a trade or profession). 7 undertake (a course of study etc.). 8 understand (a speaker, argument, etc.). 9 take an interest in (current affairs etc.). 10 (foll. By with) provide with a sequel or successor. 11 happen after something else; ensue. 12 a be necessarily true as a consequence. B (foll. By from) result.
n. 1 supporter or devotee. 2 person who follows.
prep. After in time; as a sequel to. n. Supporters or devotees. adj. That follows or comes after.
n. Cricket instance of following on.
n. Action of following through.
n. Subsequent or continued action.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 foolishness. 2 foolish act, behaviour, idea, etc. 3 fanciful ornamental building created for display. [french folie from fol mad, *fool1]
v. Instigate or stir up (trouble, discontent, etc.).
adj. 1 (foll. By of) liking. 2 a affectionate. B doting. 3 (of beliefs etc.) Foolishly optimistic or credulous.
n. Soft sugary sweet. [french = melting: related to *fuse1]
v. (-ling) caress. [related to *fond]
n. Dish of melted cheese. [french, = melted: related to *fuse1]
n. Receptacle in a church for baptismal water. [latin fons font- fountain]
var. Of *fount2.
n. (brit. Fontanelle) membranous space in an infant's skull at the angles of the parietal bones. [latin fontanella little *fountain]
n. (us fontanel) membranous space in an infant's skull at the angles of the parietal bones. [latin fontanella little *fountain]
n. 1 a substance taken in to maintain life and growth. B solid food (food and drink). 2 mental stimulus (food for thought). [old english]
n. Substance added to food to colour or flavour it etc.
n. Series of organisms each dependent on the next for food.
n. Colloq. Person who makes a cult of food; gourmet.
n. Illness due to bacteria etc. In food.
n. Machine for chopping and mixing food.
n. Substance used as food.
n. Nourishing power of a food.
n. 1 rash, unwise, or stupid person. 2 hist. Jester; clown. 3 dupe. v. 1 deceive. 2 (foll. By into or out of) trick; cheat. 3 joke or tease. 4 (foll. By about, around) play or trifle.
n. Dessert of fruit pure with cream or custard. [perhaps from *fool1]
n. Foolish behaviour.
adj. (-ier, -iest) rashly or foolishly bold; reckless.
adj. Lacking good sense or judgement; unwise.
adj. (of a procedure, mechanism, etc.) Incapable of misuse or mistake.
n. Large size of paper, about 330 x 200 (or 400) mm. [from a watermark of a fool's cap]
n. Illusory happiness.

n. (pl. Feet) 1 a part of the leg below the ankle. B part of a sock etc. Covering this. 2 a lowest part of a page, stairs, etc. B end of a bed where the feet rest. C part of a chair, appliance, etc. On which it rests. 3 step, pace, or tread (fleet of foot). 4 (pl. Feet or foot) linear measure of 12 inches (30.48 cm). 5 metrical unit of verse forming part of a line. 6 hist. Infantry. v. 1 pay (a bill). 2 (usu. As foot it) go or traverse on foot.
n. 1 a length of tv or cinema film etc. 2 length in feet.
n. Contagious viral disease of cattle etc.
n. 1 large inflated ball of leather or plastic. 2 outdoor team game played with this.
n. (also football pools pl.) Large-scale organized gambling on the results of football matches.
n. Foot-operated brake on a vehicle.
n. Bridge for pedestrians.
n. Sound of a footstep.
n. (in tennis) placing of the foot over the baseline while serving.
n. Any of the low hills at the base of a mountain or range.
n. 1 secure place for a foot when climbing etc. 2 secure initial position.
n. 1 foothold; secure position (lost his footing). 2 operational basis. 3 relative position or status (on an equal footing). 4 (often in pl.) Foundations of a wall.
v. (-ling) (usu. Foll. By about) colloq. Potter or fiddle about. [origin uncertain]
n.pl. Row of floor-level lights at the front of a stage.
adj. Colloq. Trivial, silly.
adj. Free to act as one pleases.
n. Liveried servant.
n. Footprint.
n. Note printed at the foot of a page.
n. Hist. Unmounted highwayman.
n. Path for pedestrians; pavement.
n. Platform for the crew in a locomotive.
n. Impression left by a foot or shoe.
n. Stool, rail, etc. For the feet.
n. = *ft-se. [respelling of *ft-se]
n. Colloq. Amorous play with the feet.
adj. With sore feet, esp. From walking.
n. 1 step taken in walking. 2 sound of this.
n. Stool for resting the feet on when sitting.
n. Path for pedestrians.
n. Shoes, socks, etc.
n. Use or agility of the feet in sports, dancing, etc.
n. Dandy.

prep. 1 in the interest or to the benefit of; intended to go to (did it all for my country; these flowers are for you). 2 in defence, support, or favour of. 3 suitable or appropriate to (a dance for beginners; not for me to say). 4 in respect of or with reference to; regarding (usual for ties to be worn; ready for bed). 5 representing or in place of (mp for lincoln; here for my uncle). 6 in exchange with, at the price of, corresponding to (swapped it for a cake; give me 5 for it; bought it for 5; word for word). 7 as a consequence of (fined for speeding; decorated for bravery; here's 5 for your trouble). 8 a with a view to; in the hope or quest of; in order to get (go for a walk; send for a doctor; did it for the money). B on account of (could not speak for laughing). 9 to reach; towards (left for rome). 10 so as to start promptly at (meet at seven for eight). 11 through or over (a distance or period); during (walked for miles). 12 as being (for the last time; i for one refuse). 13 in spite of; notwithstanding (for all your fine words). 14 considering or making due allowance in respect of (good for a beginner). conj. Because, since, seeing that.
prefix forming verbs etc. Meaning: 1 away, off (forget; forgive). 2 prohibition (forbid). 3 abstention or neglect (forgo; forsake). [old english]
n. 1 food for horses and cattle. 2 searching for food. v. 1 search for food; rummage. 2 collect food from. 3 get by foraging. [germanic: related to *fodder]
n. Infantry undress cap.
conj. Archaic because, since. [from for as much]
n. Sudden attack; raid. v. Make a foray. [french: related to *fodder]
(also forbad) past of *forbid.
v. (past forbore; past part. Forborne) formal abstain or desist (from) (could not forbear (from) speaking out; forbore to mention it). [old english: related to *bear1]
var. Of *forebear.
n. Patient self-control; tolerance.

v. (forbidding; past forbade or forbad; past part. Forbidden) 1 (foll. By to + infin.) Order not (i forbid you to go). 2 refuse to allow (a thing, or a person to have a thing). 3 refuse a person entry to.

n. Parliamentary vote not subject to party discipline.
n. Us motorway.
n. Driving wheel of a bicycle, able to revolve with the pedals at rest.
v. 1 ride a bicycle with the pedals at rest. 2 act without constraint.
n. 1 power of acting independently of necessity or fate. 2 ability to act without coercion (did it of my own free will).
n. Hist. Non-communist countries' collective name for themselves.

v. (-zing; past froze; past part. Frozen) 1 a turn into ice or another solid by cold. B make or become rigid from the cold. 2 be or feel very cold. 3 cover or become covered with ice. 4 (foll. By to, together) adhere by frost. 5 refrigerate (food) below freezing point. 6 a make or become motionless through fear, surprise, etc. B (as frozen adj) devoid of emotion (frozen smile). 7 make (assets etc.) Unrealizable. 8 fix (prices, wages, etc.) At a certain level. 9 stop (the movement in a film). n. 1 period or state of frost. 2 fixing or stabilization of prices, wages, etc. 3 (in full freeze-frame) still film-shot.
v. Preserve (food) by freezing and then drying in a vacuum.
n. Refrigerated cabinet etc. For preserving frozen food at very low temperatures.
n. Period or state of extreme cold.
n. Temperature at which a liquid, esp. Water, freezes.

n. 1 transport of goods in containers or by water or air, or (us) by land. 2 goods transported; cargo, load. 3 charge for the transport of goods. v. Transport as or load with freight. [low german or dutch vrecht]
n. 1 ship or aircraft for carrying freight. 2 us freight-wagon.
n. Train carrying goods in containers.
adj. 1 of france, its people, or language. 2 having french characteristics. n. 1 the french language. 2 (the french) (pl.) The people of france. 3 colloq. Dry vermouth.
n. Kidney or haricot bean as unripe sliced pods or ripe seeds.
n. Long crisp loaf.
n. Canadian whose principal language is french.
n. A kind of talc used for marking cloth, as a dry lubricant, etc.
n. Salad dressing of seasoned vinegar and oil.
n.pl. (or french fries) us potato chips.
n. Coiled brass wind instrument with a wide bell.
v. (-ies, -ied) (usu. As frenchified adj.) Colloq. Make french in form, manners, etc.
n. Open-mouthed kiss.
n. Absence without permission.
n. Colloq. Condom.
n. Man of french birth or nationality.
n. Shellac polish for wood.
n. Glazed door in an outside wall.
n. Woman of french birth or nationality.
adj. (also phrenetic) 1 frantic, frenzied. 2 fanatic.
n. (pl. -ies) wild or delirious excitement, agitation, or fury. v. (-ies, -ied) (usu. As frenzied adj.) Drive to frenzy.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 commonness of occurrence. 2 frequent occurrence. 3 rate of recurrence (of a vibration etc.); number of repetitions in a given time, esp. Per second. [related to *frequent]
n. Electronics modulation by varying carrier-wave frequency.
adj. 1 occurring often or in close succession. 2 habitual, constant. v. Attend or go to habitually.
gram. adj. (of a verb etc.) Expressing frequent repetition or intensity. n. Frequentative verb etc.
n. (pl. -s) painting done in water-colour on a wall or ceiling before the plaster is dry. [italian, = fresh]

adj. 1 newly made or obtained. 2 a other, different; new (start a fresh page; fresh ideas). B additional (fresh supplies). 3 (foll. By from) lately arrived. 4 not stale, musty, or faded. 5 (of food) not preserved; newly caught, grown, etc. 6 not salty (fresh water). 7 a pure, untainted, refreshing (fresh air). B bright and pure in colour (fresh complexion). 8 (of wind) brisk. 9 colloq. Cheeky; amorously impudent. 10 inexperienced. adv. Newly, recently (esp. In comb.: fresh-baked).
v. 1 make or become fresh. 2 (foll. By up) a wash, tidy oneself, etc. B revive.
n. Colloq. First-year student at university or (us) high school.
n. 1 rush of fresh water flowing into the sea. 2 flood of a river.
n. = *fresher.
attrib. Adj. (of fish etc.) Not of the sea.
v. (-tt-) 1 be worried or distressed. 2 worry, vex. 3 wear or consume by gnawing or rubbing. n. Worry, vexation. [old english: related to *for, *eat]
n. Ornamental pattern of straight lines joined usu. At right angles. v. (-tt-) embellish with a fret or with carved or embossed work. [french freter]
n. Each of a series of bars or ridges on the finger-board of a guitar etc. To guide fingering. [origin unknown]
adj. Anxious, irritable.
n. Narrow saw on a frame for cutting thin wood in patterns.
n. Ornamental work in wood done with a fretsaw.
adj. Of freud, his theories, or his method of psychoanalysis. n. Follower of freud.
n. Unintentional verbal error revealing subconscious feelings.
Abbr. Friday.
adj. Easily crumbled.
n. Member of a male non-enclosed roman catholic order, e.g. Carmelites and franciscans. [latin frater brother]
n. Tincture of benzoin etc. Used esp. As an inhalant.
n. (pl. -ies) monastery for friars.
n. Pieces of meat served in a thick sauce. v. (fricassees, fricasseed) make a fricassee of. [french]
adj. (of a consonant) sounded by friction of the breath in a narrow opening. n. Such a consonant (e.g. F, th). [latin frico rub]
n. 1 rubbing of one object against another. 2 the resistance encountered in so moving. 3 clash of wills, opinions, etc.
n. Day of the week following thursday. adv. Colloq. 1 on friday. 2 (fridays) on fridays; each friday. [old english]
n. Colloq. = *refrigerator. [abbreviation]
n. Combined refrigerator and freezer.

n. 1 person one likes and chooses to spend time with (usu. Without sexual or family bonds). 2 sympathizer, helper. 3 ally or neutral person (friend or foe?). 4 person already mentioned (our friend at the bank). 5 regular supporter of an institution. 6 (friend) quaker. [old english]

adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 outgoing, well-disposed, kindly. 2 a (often foll. By with) on amicable terms. B not hostile. 3 (in comb.) Not harming; helping (ozone-friendly; user-friendly). 4 = *user-friendly. n. (pl. -ies) = *friendly match. adv. In a friendly manner.
n. Match played for enjoyment rather than competition.
n. Insurance society insuring against illness etc.
n. Friendly relationship or feeling.
var. Of *fryer.
n. One of a breed of black and white dairy cattle orig. From friesland. [var. Of *frisian]
n. 1 part of an entablature between the architrave and cornice. 2 horizontal band of sculpture filling this. 3 band of decoration, esp. At the top of a wall. [latin phrygium (opus) phrygian (work)]
v. (-gg-) coarse slang 1 = *fuck v. 2 masturbate. [perhaps imitative]
n. 1 naval escort-vessel. 2 hist. Warship. [french from italian]
n. 1 a sudden or extreme fear. B instance of this (gave me a fright). 2 grotesque-looking person or thing.
v. 1 fill with fright (the bang frightened me; frightened of dogs). 2 (foll. By away, off, out of, into) drive by fright.
adj. 1 a dreadful, shocking. B ugly. 2 colloq. Extremely bad. 3 colloq. Extreme (frightful rush).
adj. 1 unfriendly, cold (frigid stare). 2 (of a woman) sexually unresponsive. 3 (esp. Of a climate or air) cold.
n. 1 strip of gathered or pleated material as an ornamental edging. 2 (in pl.) Unnecessary embellishments. v. Decorate with a frill.

n. 1 border of tassels or loose threads. 2 front hair hanging over the forehead. 3 outer limit of an area, population, etc. (often attrib.: fringe theatre). 4 unimportant area or part. v. (-ging) 1 adorn with a fringe. 2 serve as a fringe to. [latin fimbria]
n. Employee's benefit additional to salary.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 showy finery, esp. In dress. 2 empty display in speech, literary style, etc. 3 (usu. In pl.) Knick-knacks. [french friperie]
n. Propr. Concave plastic disc for skimming through the air as an outdoor game. [perhaps from frisbie bakery pie-tins]
adj. Of friesland. n. Native or language of friesland. [latin frisii (n. Pl.) From old frisian frisa]
v. 1 leap or skip playfully. 2 slang search (a person) for a weapon etc. By feeling. n. 1 playful leap or skip. 2 slang frisking of a person. [french frisque lively]
adj. (-ier, -iest) lively, playful.
n. Emotional thrill. [french]
var. Of *firth.
n. (pl. -ies) 1 plant with bell-like flowers. 2 butterfly with red-brown wings chequered with black. [latin fritillus dice-box]
v. (usu. Foll. By away) waste (money, time, etc.) Triflingly. [obsolete fritter(s) fragments]
n. Fruit, meat, etc. Coated in batter and fried. [french friture from latin frigo *fry1]
adj. 1 not serious, silly, shallow. 2 paltry, trifling.
v. Form (hair) into tight curls. n. Frizzed hair or state. [french friser]
v. (-ling) 1 fry or cook with a sizzling noise. 2 (often foll. By up) burn or shrivel. [obsolete frizz: related to *fry1, with imitative ending]
v. (-ling) form into tight curls. n. Frizzled hair. [perhaps related to *frizz]
adj. (-ier, -iest) in tight curls.
adv. Back (now only in to and fro: see *to). [old norse: related to *from]
n. 1 woman's or girl's dress. 2 monk's or priest's gown. 3 smock. [french from germanic]
n. Man's long-skirted coat.
n. 1 small smooth tailless leaping amphibian. 2 (frog) slang offens. Frenchman.
n. Horny substance in the sole of a horse's foot. [origin uncertain: perhaps a use of *frog1]
n. Ornamental coat-fastening of a button and loop. [origin unknown]
n. Person with a rubber suit, flippers, and an oxygen supply for underwater swimming.
v. Hustle forward with the arms pinned behind.
n. Frog's eggs.
v. (-ck-) play about cheerfully. n. 1 cheerful play. 2 prank. 3 merry party. [dutch vrolijk (adj.) From vro glad]
adj. Merry, playful.

prep. Expressing separation or origin, followed by: 1 person, place, time, etc., that is the starting-point (dinner is served from 8; from start to finish). 2 place, object, etc. At a specified distance etc. (10 miles from rome; far from sure). 3 a source (gravel from a pit; quotations from shaw). B giver or sender (not heard from her). 4 thing or person avoided, deprived, etc. (released him from prison; took his gun from him). 5 reason, cause, motive (died from fatigue; did it from jealousy). 6 thing distinguished or unlike (know black from white). 7 lower limit (from 10 to 20 boats). 8 state changed for another (from being poor he became rich). 9 adverb or preposition of time or place (from long ago; from abroad; from under the bed).
n. Smooth low-fat soft cheese.
n. Leaflike part of a fern or palm. [latin frons frond- leaf]
n. 1 side or part most prominent or important, or nearer the spectator or direction of motion (front of the house). 2
n. 1 front of a building. 2 land next to a street or water etc. 3 extent of a front. 4 a the way a thing faces. B outlook.
adj. 1 of or on the front (frontal view; frontal attack). 2 of the forehead (frontal bone).
n. Seats in parliament occupied by leading members of the government and opposition.
n. Mp occupying the front bench.
n. 1 a border between two countries. B district on each side of this. 2 limits of attainment or knowledge in a subject. 3 us borders between settled and unsettled country.
n. Illustration facing the title-page of a book. [latin: related to *front, specio look]
n. Foremost part of an army or group under attack.
n. Favourite in a race etc.

n. 1 a frozen dew or vapour. B consistent temperature below freezing point. 2 cold dispiriting atmosphere. v. 1 (usu. Foll. By over, up) become covered with frost. 2 a cover with or as with frost. B injure (a plant etc.) With frost. 3 make (glass) non-transparent by roughening its surface. [old english: related to *freeze]
n. Injury to body tissues due to freezing.
n. Icing.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 cold with frost. 2 covered with or as with frost. 3 unfriendly in manner.
n. 1 foam. 2 idle or amusing talk etc. v. 1 emit or gather froth. 2 cause (beer etc.) To foam.
v. 1 wrinkle one's brows, esp. In displeasure or concentration. 2 (foll. By at, on) disapprove of. n. 1 act of frowning. 2 look of displeasure or concentration. [french]
adj. (-ier, -iest) fusty, stuffy. [var. Of *frowzy]
adj. (also frowsy) (-ier, -iest) 1 fusty. 2 slatternly, dingy. [origin unknown]
past of *freeze.
past part. Of *freeze.
abbr. Fellow of the royal society.
v. (-ies, -ied) 1 bear fruit. 2 make fruitful. [latin: related to *fruit]
n. Sugar in honey, fruits, etc. [latin: related to *fruit]
adj. 1 sparing or thrifty, esp. As regards food. 2 meagre, cheap.

n. 1 a seed-bearing part of a plant or tree; this as food. B these collectively. 2 (usu. In pl.) Vegetables, grains, etc. As food (fruits of the earth). 3 (usu. In pl.) Profits, rewards. v. (cause to) bear fruit. [latin fructus from fruor enjoy]
n. Cake containing dried fruit.
n. Diced fruit salad.
n. Dealer in fruit.
adj. 1 producing much fruit. 2 successful, profitable.
n. 1 bearing of fruit. 2 realization of aims or hopes. [latin: related to *fruit]
n. Juice of fruit, esp. As a drink.
adj. 1 not bearing fruit. 2 useless, unsuccessful.
n. Coin-operated gaming machine using symbols representing fruit.
n. Fructose.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 a of fruit. B tasting or smelling like fruit. 2 (of a voice etc.) Deep and rich. 3 colloq. Slightly indecent or suggestive.
n. Dowdy unattractive woman.
v. (-ting) 1 make (efforts) ineffective. 2 prevent (a person) from achieving a purpose. 3 (as frustrated adj.) A discontented because unable to achieve one's aims. B sexually unfulfilled.
n. (pl. -ta or -s) geom. Remaining part of a decapitated cone or pyramid. [latin, = piece cut off]
v. (fries, fried) cook or be cooked in hot fat. n. (pl. Fries) 1 offal, usu. Eaten fried (lamb's fry). 2 fried food, esp. Meat. [latin frigo]
n.pl. Young or newly hatched fishes. [old norse, = seed]
n. (also frier) 1 person who fries. 2 vessel for frying esp. Fish.
n. Shallow pan used in frying.
n. Colloq. Fried bacon, eggs, etc.
abbr. Foot, feet.
abbr. Financial times stock exchange 100 share index (based on the share values of britain's largest public companies).
n. Shrub with drooping red, purple, or white flowers. [fuchs, name of a botanist]

coarse slang v. 1 (often absol. Or as int. Expressing annoyance) curse (a person or thing). 2 have sexual intercourse (with). 3 (foll. By about, around) mess about; fool around. 4 (as fucking adj., adv.) Expressing annoyance etc. n. 1 a act of sexual intercourse. B partner in this. 2 slightest amount (don't give a fuck).
although widely used, fuck is still considered to be the most offensive word in the english language by many people. In discussions about bad language it is frequently referred to as the f word.
n. Coarse slang bungle or muddle.
v. (-ling) confuse or stupefy, esp. With alcohol. n. 1 confusion. 2 intoxication. [origin unknown]
slang adj. Old-fashioned or quaintly fussy. n. (pl. -ies) such a person. [origin unknown]
n. 1 soft toffee-like sweet made of milk, sugar, butter, etc. 2 piece of dishonesty or faking. v. (-ging) make or do clumsily or dishonestly; fake (fudge the results). [origin uncertain]
var. Of *fhrer.

n. 1 material for burning or as a source of heat, power, or nuclear energy. 2 food as a source of energy. 3 thing that sustains or inflames passion etc. v. (-ll-; us -l-) 1 supply with, take in, or get, fuel. 2 inflame (feeling etc.). [french from latin]
n. Cell producing electricity direct from a chemical reaction.
n. Colloq. Close stuffy atmosphere.
n. (often foll. By from) person who flees, e.g. From justice or an enemy. adj. 1 fleeing. 2 transient, fleeting. [latin fugio flee]
n. Piece of music in which a short melody or phrase is introduced by one part and taken up and developed by others.
n. (also fuehrer) tyrannical leader. [german]

comb. Form forming: 1 adjectives from a nouns, meaning full of or having qualities of (beautiful; masterful). B adjectives (direful). C verbs, meaning apt to (forgetful). 2 nouns (pl. -fuls) meaning amount that fills (handful; spoonful).
n. (pl. -s or -cra) point on which a lever is supported. [latin fulcio to prop]
v. (us fulfill) (-ll-) 1 carry out (a task, prophecy, promise, etc.). 2 a satisfy (conditions, a desire, prayer, etc.). B (as fulfilled adj.) Completely happy. 3 answer (a purpose).
v. (brit. Fulfil) (-ll-) 1 carry out (a task, prophecy, promise, etc.). 2 a satisfy (conditions, a desire, prayer, etc.). B (as fulfilled adj.) Completely happy. 3 answer (a purpose).

adj. 1 holding all it can (bucket is full; full of water). 2 having eaten all one can or wants. 3 abundant, copious, satisfying (a full life; full details). 4 (foll. By of) having an abundance of (full of vitality). 5 (foll. By of) engrossed in (full of himself). 6 complete, perfect (full membership; in full bloom). 7 (of tone) deep and clear. 8 plump, rounded (full figure). 9 (of clothes) ample, hanging in folds. adv. 1 very (knows full well). 2 quite, fully (full six miles). 3 exactly (full on the nose).
v. Clean and thicken (cloth). [from *fuller]
n. Defensive player near the goal in football, hockey, etc.
adj. 1 vigorous, hearty, sensual. 2 not hybrid.
adj. Fully developed.
n. Provision of bed and all meals at a hotel etc.
adj. Rich in quality, tone, etc.
n. Person who fulls cloth.
adj. 1 (of a nude figure) fully exposed at the front. 2 explicit, unrestrained.
n. 1 maximum attendance at a theatre etc. 2 hand in poker with three of a kind and a pair.
adj. 1 not shortened. 2 (of a mirror, portrait, etc.) Showing the whole figure.
n. 1 moon with its whole disc illuminated. 2 time of this.
n. Being full.
adj. Not reduced in size, complete.
n. 1 punctuation mark (.) At the end of a sentence or an abbreviation. 2 complete cessation.
n. Completion of a normal pregnancy.
adj. For or during the whole of the working week (full-time job). adv. On a full-time basis (work full-time).
n. Person who does a full-time job.
adv. 1 completely, entirely (am fully aware). 2 at least (fully 60).
adj. (of women's clothing) shaped to fit closely.
n. Arctic sea bird related to the petrel. [old norse: related to *foul, mar gull]
adj. 1 fulminating. 2 (of a disease etc.) Developing suddenly. [latin: related to *fulminate]
v. (-ting) 1 criticize loudly and forcefully. 2 explode violently; flash.
adj. Excessive, cloying, insincere (fulsome praise).
the phrase fulsome praise is sometimes wrongly used to mean generous praise rather than excessive praise.
v. (-ling) 1 use the hands awkwardly, grope about. 2 handle clumsily or nervously (fumbled the ball). n. Act of fumbling. [low german fummeln]

n. (usu. In pl.) Exuded gas, smoke, or vapour, esp. When harmful or unpleasant. v. (-ming) 1 emit fumes or as fumes. 2 be very angry. 3 subject (oak, film, etc.) To fumes to darken. [latin fumus smoke]
v. (-ting) disinfect or purify with fumes.
n. 1 lively or playful amusement. 2 source of this. 3 mockery, ridicule (figure of fun). attrib. Adj. Colloq. Amusing, enjoyable (a fun thing to do).
the use of fun as an attributive adjective is common in informal use, but is considered incorrect by some people.

n. 1 a proper or necessary role, activity, or purpose. B official or professional duty. 2 public or social occasion. 3 math. Quantity whose value depends on the varying values of others. v. Fulfil a function, operate. [latin fungor funct- perform]
adj. 1 of or serving a function. 2 practical rather than attractive. 3 affecting the function of a bodily organ but not its structure.
n. Belief that a thing's function should determine its design.
n. (pl. -ies) official performing certain duties.
n. 1 permanently available stock (fund of knowledge). 2 sum of money, esp. Set apart for a purpose. 3 (in pl.) Money resources. v. 1 provide with money. 2 make (a debt) permanent at fixed interest.
adj. Of or being a base or foundation; essential, primary. n. 1 (usu. In pl.) Fundamental principle. 2 mus. Fundamental note.
n. Strict adherence to traditional religious beliefs or doctrines.
n. Mus. Lowest note of a chord.
n. Elementary particle.
n. Person raising money for a cause, enterprise, etc.
n. 1 ceremonial burial or cremation of a corpse. 2 slang one's (usu. Unpleasant) concern (that's your funeral). attrib. Adj. Of or used at funerals. [latin funus funer-]
n. Undertaker.
n. Establishment where corpses are prepared for funerals.
adj. Of or used at funerals.
adj. 1 of or appropriate to a funeral. 2 dismal, dark.
n. Fair with amusements and sideshows.
n. Substance that kills fungus.
adj. Fungus-like. n. Fungoid plant.
n. (pl. -gi or -guses) 1 mushroom, toadstool, or allied plant, including moulds, feeding on organic matter. 2 med. Spongy morbid growth.
adj. (of a mountain railway) operating by cable with ascending and descending cars counterbalanced. n. Funicular railway. [latin funiculus diminutive of funis rope]
slang n. 1 fear, panic. 2 coward. v. 1 evade through fear. 2 be afraid (of). [origin uncertain]
n. Slang funky music. [origin uncertain]
adj. (-ier, -iest) slang (esp. Of jazz or rock music) earthy, bluesy, with a heavy rhythm.

n. 1 tube widening at the top, for pouring liquid etc. Into a small opening. 2 metal chimney on a steam engine or steamship. v. (-ll-; us -l-) guide or move through or as through a funnel. [provenal fonilh from latin (in)fundibulum]
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 amusing, comical. 2 strange, peculiar. 3 colloq. A slightly unwell. B eccentric.
n. Part of the elbow over which a very sensitive nerve passes.
n. Colloq. Uncompetitive sponsored run for charity.

n. 1 a short fine soft animal hair. B hide with fur on it, used esp. For clothing. 2 garment of or lined with fur. 3 (collect.) Animals with fur. 4 fur-like coating on the tongue, in a kettle, etc. v. (-rr-) 1 (esp. As furred adj.) Line or trim with fur. 2 (often foll. By up) (of a kettle etc.) Become coated with fur.
n. 1 (in pl.) Showy ornaments. 2 archaic gathered strip or border of a skirt or petticoat. [french falbala]
v. (often foll. By up) = *refurbish. [french from germanic]
adj. Forked, branched. v. (-ting) fork, divide.
adj. 1 very angry. 2 raging, frantic.
v. 1 roll up and secure (a sail etc.). 2 become furled. [french ferler]
n. Eighth of a mile. [old english: related to *furrow, *long1]
n. Leave of absence, esp. Military. v. Us 1 grant furlough to. 2 spend furlough. [dutch: related to *for-, *leave1]
n. 1 enclosed structure for intense heating by fire, esp. Of metals or water. 2 very hot place. [latin fornax from fornus oven]
v. 1 provide (a house, room, etc.) With furniture. 2 (often foll. By with) supply. [french from germanic]
adj. (of a house etc.) Let with furniture.
n. 1 person who sells furniture. 2 person who furnishes.
n.pl. Furniture and fitments in a house, room, etc.
n. 1 movable equipment of a house, room, etc., e.g. Tables, beds. 2 naut. Ship's equipment. 3 accessories, e.g. The handles and lock on a door. [french: related to *furnish]
n. (brit. Furore) 1 uproar; fury. 2 enthusiastic admiration. [latin: related to *fury]
n. (us furor) 1 uproar; fury. 2 enthusiastic admiration. [latin: related to *fury]
n. Dealer in or dresser of furs. [french]
n. 1 narrow trench made by a plough. 2 rut, groove, wrinkle. 3 ship's track. v. 1 plough. 2 make furrows in. [old english]
adj. (-ier, -iest) like or covered with fur.

adv. (also farther) 1 more distant in space or time. 2 to a greater extent, more (will enquire further). 3 in addition (i may add further). adj. (also farther) 1 more distant or advanced. 2 more, additional (further details). v. Promote or favour (a scheme etc.). [old english: related to *forth]
the form farther is used esp. With reference to physical distance, although further is preferred by many people even in this sense.
n. Furthering of a scheme etc.
n. Education for those above school age.
adv. In addition, besides.
(also farthest) adj. Most distant. adv. To or at the greatest distance.
the form farthest is used esp. With reference to physical distance, although furthest is preferred by many people even in this sense.
adj. Sly, stealthy.

n. (pl. -ies) 1 a wild and passionate anger. B fit of rage. 2 violence of a storm, disease, etc. 3 (fury) (usu. In pl.) (in greek mythology) avenging goddess. 4 avenging spirit. 5 angry or malignant woman.
n. = *gorse.

v. (-sing) 1 melt with intense heat. 2 blend into one whole by melting. 3 provide (an electric circuit) with a fuse. 4 a (of an appliance) fail owing to the melting of a fuse. B cause to do this. n. Device with a strip or wire of easily melted metal placed in an electric circuit so as to interrupt an excessive current by melting. [latin fundo fus- melt]
(also fuze) n. 1 device of combustible matter for igniting a bomb or explosive charge. 2 component made of this in a shell, mine, etc. v. (-sing) fit a fuse to. [latin fusus spindle]
n. Body of an aeroplane. [french from fuseau spindle]
adj. That can be melted.
n. Hist. Light musket. [latin focus fire]
n. Member of any of several british regiments formerly armed with fusils. [french: related to *fusil]
n. 1 period of continuous discharge of firearms. 2 sustained outburst of criticism etc.
n. 1 fusing or melting. 2 blending. 3 coalition. 4 = *nuclear fusion. [latin: related to *fuse1]
n. 1 excited commotion, bustle. 2 excessive concern about a trivial thing. 3 sustained protest or dispute. v. 1 behave with nervous concern. 2 agitate, worry.
n. Colloq. Person given to fussing.
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 inclined to fuss. 2 over-elaborate. 3 fastidious.
n. 1 thick usu. Dark twilled cotton cloth. 2 bombast. adj. 1 made of fustian. 2 bombastic. 3 worthless. [french]
adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 musty, stuffy. 2 antiquated.
adj. 1 useless, ineffectual. 2 frivolous.
n. Japanese quilted mattress used as a bed; this sold with a low wooden frame, often convertible into a couch. [japanese]

adj. 1 about to happen, be, or become. 2 a of time to come. B gram. (of a tense) describing an event yet to happen. n. 1 time to come. 2 future events. 3 future condition of a person, country, etc. 4 prospect of success etc. (no future in it). 5 gram. Future tense. 6 (in pl.) Stock exch. Goods etc. Sold for future delivery.
n. Gram. Tense giving the sense will have done.
n. 20th-century artistic movement departing from traditional forms and celebrating technology and dynamism.
adj. 1 suitable for the future; ultra-modern. 2 of futurism.
n. (pl. -ies) literary 1 future time. 2 (in sing. Or pl.) Future events.
n. Forecasting of the future, esp. From present trends.
var. Of *fuse2.
